dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine a Japanese woodblock painting brought to life. Tw ducks bob in the water, a spectacular thatched pagoda ris behind them. The trees blaze with the colors of late autu Everything is peaceful and placid until -- SPLASH! Nets slam down between the ducks. As the birds bu into flight, honking their displeasure, we realize that t nets are connected to long bamboo handles. Four men in military uniforms wield the odd contraptions: two wear the blue of the Japanese navy and two are wester

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: As the Japanese officers advance on a new pair of ducks, CAPTAIN BERNARD RAWLINGS, 48, gives his net a disgusted l He speaks with an English accent.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: This is bloody ridiculous. His companion, EDWIN LAYTON, 34, wears the uniform of a lieutenant commander in the US Navy. Layton has a dry sen of humor and a perpetual worried squint -- he sees troubl lurking behind every corner.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Wasn't your empire built on ridiculous traditions?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: Don't defend them, Layton. You might speak their language, but they still think you're a barbarian. Layton gestures at their idyllic surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Be honest... won't you miss this place when you're gone? Rawlings snorts.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: The next time I see the little buggers, I hope it's through the sights of a fourteen-inch gun. A HONK from the lake catches their attention -- one of th Japanese officers has successfully netted a duck. Layton shouts in subtitled Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, Kimura-san. The officer turns and stiffly bows. Layton bows back and then glances at Rawlings.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If things keep heading in this direction, you'll get your wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiters carve raw duck in the corner as a group of Japane and foreign officers eat sukiyaki at a traditional table. Japanese OFFICER is concluding a fiery toast. He turns to the Emperor's portrait and raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Banzai! Banzai! Banzai! The officer drains his glass in a gulp, and the other men immediately follow his lead. It's impossible to miss the naked machismo in this room: no Japanese officer is going be shamed in front of a foreigner and vice versa. As the men refill their glasses with scotch from ceramic jugs, Rawlings stands to toast. His face is flushed.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN RAWLINGS
dialogues.text: On behalf of the British Empire, I want to thank Admiral Yamamoto for this invitation. May our nations forever remain partners on the seas. All eyes swing to the head of the table where the handsom and charismatic ADMIRAL YAMAMOTO, 52, sits. The words han in the air for a long moment before Yamamoto raises his o sake glass and drains it. The other men practically trip over each other to match h Layton, however, just touches the glass to his lips -- seemingly impervious to the social pressure of the situat As Layton sets down the glass, he notices Yamamoto starin at him. Their eyes meet for an awkward moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds of the party spill through the thin paper of a shoji door as Layton examines a set of woodblock prints. Yamamoto enters, sliding the door closed behind him. He glances at Layton and then speaks in subtitled Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: You don't like whiskey? Layton turns, caught off guard. But he recovers quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could ask you the same question, admiral. I have it on good authority that your glass is filled with tea. Yamamoto is briefly taken aback -- he's rarely challenged but then he gives Layton a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: An old Chinese trick. (beat ) What else have you learned during your time in Japan? Layton hears the dangerous subtext in that question: are a spy? He therefore does his best to shrug it off.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I'm just the assistant naval attaché.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Which is why I know that you must have an opinion. I was once our naval attaché in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: After your years at Harvard. Yamamoto smiles again -- impressed that Layton has done h homework. He responds in fluent English.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Like you, I thought there was value in studying a potential adversary.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: (also English) And what did you learn?

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Do you know the Japanese nickname for America?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Beikoku.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Exactly. 'Rice country.' A place of endless resources. And I saw with my own eyes the vast oilfields of Texas. The steelyards of Pittsburgh. The factories of Detroit.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I heard you told the prime minster that Japan can't win a war with the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. I said that we couldn't win a long war.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I heard another rumor that your life might be in danger. The Nationalists think you're too moderate. Yamamoto is silent for a long moment, and Layton wonders he has pushed his luck too far. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Japan is at a crossroads. We are eager to become a world power, yet we are dangerously reliant on outside forces. We get 80 percent of our oil and scrap metal from your country. If that supply is threatened, it will force us into drastic measures. Layton knows exactly what Yamamoto means by "drastic measures," and the purpose of their conversation abruptly becomes clear to him.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: You want me to pass this information along to Washington.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Tell them not to push us into a corner. Your government must give those of us who are more reasonable a chance to carry the day.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Nobody wants a war. Yamamoto shakes his head, expression grim.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: I wish that were true. Yamamoto sticks out his hand, and the two men shake. As t admiral starts back toward his party --

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sayonara, Layton-san. And then the door slides shut and he's gone. As Layton st after him, lost in thought, the rising GROWL of engines b to pound at our ears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stiff ocean breeze almost knocks us sideways as the v teak deck pitches up and down in the steady rollers of th Pacific. We're aboard...  5. ...the aircraft carrier USS ENTERPRISE. Mankind's latest greatest superweapon. It's been barely three decades since the Wright Brothers went aloft in their glorified kite, and now this ship -- 20,000 tons of American steel -- can attack a target with warplanes, escape at 30 knots, and hit a new target the n afternoon a thousand miles away. At least that's the theory. It has never been tested. SUPER: "FOUR YEARS LATER. 175 MILES WEST OF PEARL HARBOR. The relentless GROWL is coming from four Douglas SBD Daun dive bombers, which are warming up their engines. The SBD are built for war with snub wings and a sturdy airframe. We PUSH past the planes until we reach a lone figure star out at the ocean. DICK BEST, 31, wears the leather bomber jacket of a pilot and oozes from every pore with what Tom Wolfe will someday call "the right stuff." He might be th top pilot in the whole damn Navy -- and he knows it. Best remains locked on the ocean as another pilot strides behind him. CLARENCE DICKINSON, 29, is the Goose to Best' Maverick. He's lanky with a northern Florida drawl. Best speaks without looking at Dickinson.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: War is coming.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: You've been saying that for years.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Yeah, but now I mean it. Best flicks his head at the bridge behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The old man feels it too. That's why we've been flying double scouting missions this whole trip.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Then we better get in some R&R while we can. I'm going to haul ass into Pearl this morning ahead of the fleet and hit the beach with Cliff.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I can't go with you boys. (off Dickinson's look) They're holding back Scouting Six. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Well, I'd hate to be you.  6. Dickinson grins, sticking it to his friend. Best is about reply, but they're interrupted by the arrival of BILL MIL 24, Dickinson's radioman. He salutes the pilots, eyes loc on his commander.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Morning, sir. The aircraft is spotted. Best gives Miller a long look -- he seems jumpy.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: You okay, Miller?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: It's my last day of sea duty, sir. And I'm the only one from my radio class who hasn't crashed.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Miller. Even Mr. Dickinson can fly from here to Pearl Harbor without getting you wet. Dickinson snorts at the jab and then starts toward the wa planes. But then he glances back.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Me and Cliff will be thinking of you when we're lying on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I hope a shark bites your dick off. Dickinson smiles to himself as he continues to his SBD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battleship gleams on a gorgeous Sunday morning in Pea Harbor. A bleary-eyed band gathers around the flag to rai the colors while a crew of sailors put out folding chairs LT. CLIFF JANZ, 31, emerges onto the deck. He looks like Navy recruiting poster with blue eyes and a square jaw. O of the men setting up the chairs (SULLY) catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Hey, lieutenant. How come I've got to set up the chairs for church even though I don't believe in God? Cliff gives Sully a dry look.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Because your only religion is chasing girls. And the Navy isn't going to pay you for that. As the other men smile, Cliff continues toward the flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hurry this up, gentlemen. I've got a date with a beach and a beer. The drone of an engine abruptly catches Cliff's attention plane is approaching the ship at a high speed. ~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff stares at the aircraft, his brain processing the sh of the wings. And then he shouts --

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get down! RAT-TAT-TAT! Bullets PING off the battleship's armor. Cli catches a glimpse of the plane's insignia as it passes: t red emblem of the rising sun. As the men scramble back to their feet, Cliff scans the s And that's when he sees a squadron of high-altitude bombe approaching battleship row. Dozens and dozens of planes. Sully glances at Cliff, fighting his rising panic.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Is it the Japs? But Cliff is already dashing toward the ladder that leads to the next deck. He shouts over his shoulder --

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Sound general quarters. And then he's climbing. We stay TIGHT on Cliff as he reac the top of the ladder and sprints down the exposed corrid that runs along the port side of the ship. General quarters abruptly BLARES and confused men begin t emerge from various hatches. Cliff bowls past a few of th already sweating in the heat, and then -- BOOM! A near miss shakes the deck. The percussion wave sl Cliff against the rail, and he falls, one hand clutching broken rib. But he immediately scrambles to his feet, eye locked on a ladder that leads upward. An instant later Cliff is climbing again. Bullets PING of the metal around him, but he keeps moving. He finally sho open a hatch and pulls himself into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ten-man crew stares at Cliff as he enters, white-face in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: We gotta get those planes off us. Why the hell aren't you firing? The young ENSIGN spreads his hands, helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ammo boxes are locked. Cliff grabs a fire ax from the wall and smashes it into t lock. As the door pops open, he points at the rounds insi

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: All right. Get the -- BOOM! The men are tossed to the deck as a bomb detonates somewhere on the ship. The sound is deafening in the encl space. Cliff is the first to recover.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Start firing! As Cliff turns to exit, the ensign desperately clutches h arm. His voice is distorted by Cliff's ringing ears.

dialogues.speaker: ENSIGN
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: We've gotta get this ship moving. We're a sitting duck. And then Cliff drops through the hatch and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWIN LAYTON, now 39, reads the paper as he eats breakfas with his prim wife MIRIAM, 37. The house is decorated wit knickknacks from a dozen different naval posts. Miriam gl at Layton as she stands to clear the breakfast plates.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Are you coming to church?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I have to go into the office.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: It's Sunday. (off his look) You work too hard. RING! RING! Layton's head whips around and he stares at t phone on the wall with transparent dread. It's as if he's expecting bad news. Miriam gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Want me to get it? Layton shakes his head and then stands and warily crosses the phone. He answers and listens for a beat. Miriam watc him, transfixed by the expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Tell them I'm coming.  Layton hangs up the phone, his hand shaking slightly.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Edwin, what's happening?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: The Japanese are attacking us. Her hand flies to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Where?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Layton hurries out the front door, now wearing his unifor and carrying a briefcase. A Cadillac ROADSTER skids to a halt in front of the house and LIEUTENANT PAUL CROSLEY, 2 frantically waves from the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: CROSLEY
dialogues.text: Come on. I'll give you a lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac speeds toward the promontory of Diamond Head which conceals Pearl Harbor from view. Lights flash behin them and Crosley glances in his rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CROSLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ. A motorcycle COP is trailing them. Layton turns around in his seat to look. Then --

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Pull over. (off Crosley) He's going to kill himself. Crosley hits the brakes and the Cadillac rumbles to a sto The cop gets off his bike and ambles toward them. CoP Bit fast for a Sunday --

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: The Japs are attacking Pearl Harbor. The cop stares at them, confused -- this seems like an impossible lie. Crosley raises a hand as if swearing an o

dialogues.speaker: CROSLEY
dialogues.text: It's the God's honest.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff bursts onto the bridge, breathing hard. He locks on cluster of panicked junior officers.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: We've got to get underway. An ENGINEERING OFFICER stares at Cliff's leg.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEERING OFFICER
dialogues.text: Jesus, Cliff. You've been hit. Cliff glances down and sees that blood has soaked his rig pant leg -- he's been shot in the calf. But he shrugs it and limps over to the set of gauges that register the ste pressure. He stares at them as if he's been betrayed.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Goddammit.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEERING OFFICER
dialogues.text: We just need five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: We don't have -- KABOOM! Cliff glances out the front window of the bridge just_as the Arizona's forward magazine detonates. The dec ripples with the force of the blast, and the bridge tilts the massive battleship's bow rises twenty feet in the air An instant later the white-hot flash of the explosion sur through the bridge, briefly blinding us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac barrels down the road -- now escorted by the motorcycle cop -- until Crosley abruptly stands on his br He's staring through the windshield, transfixed by someth and we REVERSE to reveal... ...the iconic image for the first time: towering columns smoke rise from Battleship Row as Japanese bombers attack A_ giant mushroom cloud rises from Arizona, followed by a blast wave racing toward us across the water. It seems impossible that anyone could survive that explosion. As Crosley ducks for cover, we go CLOSE on Layton. The ma fireball is reflected in his glasses, and his expression difficult to decipher. He's horrified, of course. But not surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two SBDs fly in formation above Barbers Point. Smoke rise in the distance from Pearl Harbor.  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickinson is on the stick. Miller is seated behind him fa backwards -- he's responsible for both the radio equipmen and operating the .30 caliber Browning tail gun. As Dickinson squints at the distant smoke, Miller's voice echoes through the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: What is it, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Looks like Coastal Artillery went stark mad. Bet you someone's going to catch hell for it. A FLASH of metal near the sun catches Dickinson's attenti and his instincts lead him to yank on the stick. As the S lurches, he shouts into the radio --

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Incoming! The warning is too late for their wingman, who catches a full broadside of cannon fire. As his SBD explodes into f two Japanese Zero fighters scream past us. Dickinson, meanwhile, continues his roll and fires with h fixed guns. He swears, realizing that he has missed, and then yells into the intercom --

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miller. Break radio silence. And get that damn gun working! Miller flips the transmit key on his radio.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Pearl Harbor under attack by Japanese aircraft. This is no shit! And then Miller is slammed into his seat as Dickinson tak wildly evasive action. He nevertheless manages to pull a string of ammo from a box and feed it into the Browning.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: On our six! RAT-TAT-TAT! Miller fires in long bursts, swinging the gu from side to side, until -- BOOM! Their right wing explodes into flame as a round of cannon fire riddles the SBD. The fucking Zeros are everyw Dickinson yanks on the stick... ...but it's dead. The plane goes into a right spin, and Dickinson glances at the altimeter. They're just a thousa feet above the ground.  12.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miller! Bail out! As Dickinson pushes himself out of the cockpit, he catche glimpse of a lifeless Miller in the back seat -- -- and then Dickinson is tumbling in the sky. He desperat fumbles with his ripcord, the ground rushing up at him -- KABOOM! His abandoned SBD explodes in the field beneath h just as his parachute catches the air. Dickinson has only second or two to brace himself before he slams onto a dir road, hard enough that his knees buckle. He collapses to the ground and lies still for a moment -- stunned to be alive -- before rolling over and freeing hi from the silk parachute. As Dickinson orients himself, he realizes that guns are f nearby. It's a platoon of Marines lined up in formation o I op a hundred yards away, shooting with their rifles at the Japanese planes like vestiges from an earlier war. Their SERGEANT, meanwhile, is jogging down the hill towar Dickinson. He gives the pilot a long look.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: You all right, sir? Physically, yes -- by some miracle the total of Dickinson wounds is a skinned elbow. But he's hopping mad.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Get me to Hickam Field. The sergeant stares at this angry man who just fell from sky. All he can think to say is... h SERGEANT Why? Dickinson looks at the sergeant as if he's a complete idi

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: So I can get in another goddamned plane and get back up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two RADIOMEN listen through headphones, frantically transcribing chatter as a nervous ENSIGN paces behind the Best bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? The ensign turns to him, relieved to see a superior offic  13.

dialogues.speaker: ENSIGN
dialogues.text: Pearl is shooting at our guys, sir. I guess they didn't know that we were sending a squadron ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Maybe it isn't Pearl. The words hang in the air. If it isn't Pearl, then who? B glances at one of the RADIOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call Dickinson.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: I tried. He isn't responding. (off Best) We got a garbled transmission that he was under attack. And then nothing. The words land hard on Best. Has his friend been shot dow What the hell is happening? But he has no time to dwell o those questions because the other RADIOMAN tears off his headphones and snaps to attention.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: Sir! Look at this. He holds out a decoded message. Best snatches it and read

dialogues.speaker: "URGENT XX AIR RAID ON PEARL HARBOR XX THIS IS NOT A DRIL
dialogues.text: Best feels the eyes of the other men on him, so he keeps face expressionless. He hands the message to the ensign.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Take this to the admiral. The ensign starts toward the door -- too slowly for Best. conveys the urgency of the situation in a single word.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac roars up to a large brick building across th loch from the dry dock. Thick black smoke shrouds everyth as anti-aircraft fire RATTLES the windows. Layton emerges from the car and dashes into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Layton enters and finds ADMIRAL KIMMEL (commander -in-chi of the Pacific Fleet) standing in a horrified huddle with his FLAG OFFICERS. Kimmel immediately fixes on Layton.  14.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KIMMEL
dialogues.text: Here's the man who tried to warn us. If it's any satisfaction to you, Layton, you were right and we were wrong.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Sir, it's no satisfaction to me whatsoever. The room TREMBLES with an explosion. Kimmel stares out th window at a fireball from the drydock, clearly in shock. he gathers himself and then turns back to Layton.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KIMMEL
dialogues.text: You need to locate the Japanese carriers. We can't let them do this and get away scot free.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I know the man who can find them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PETTY OFFICER at the desk holds a rifle in nervous ha a flak helmet on his head. Layton hurries up to him.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Where's Rochefort?

dialogues.speaker: PETTY OFFICER
dialogues.text: On the roof, sir. Layton stares at him, confused. The roof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spent anti-aircraft bullets PING off the tin of the roof a steady (and potentially deadly) rain. But the birdlike brilliant JOSEPH ROCHEFORT, 40, ignores the danger and carefully affixes wires to a makeshift antenna. Layton bursts out of a stairwell and locks on Rochefort. camera CIRCLES them as they talk, revealing the devastati panorama in the background.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing? We need to find the Japanese fleet.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: That's what I'm trying to do. Those Army idiots think we're about to get invaded, so they shut down the phones. We can't communicate with our radio direction finder. Layton quickly does the math.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: You're building another one?  15. As Rochefort shrugs, a flaming chunk of metal THUDS into roof. Layton gives Rochefort a look.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't get killed up here. The Navy's going to need you to win this war. Rochefort ignores him, once again locked on his work. Lay nods to himself -- these men understand each other -- and then ducks back into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The modest-sized flag bridge is at the top of the carrier island, giving it a view of the flight deck. ADMIRAL WILL "BULL" HALSEY, 62, enters. He's a rugged bowling ball of human being who is beloved by his men for his honesty. Halsey glances at CAPTAIN MILES BROWNING, his operations war plans officer.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Pearl found something?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Intelligence managed to get a radio fix on the attacking fleet. Unfortunately, it's a bilateral reading. Meaning the Japs are either at 363 degrees... Browning points down at the map table, his finger tracing line due north of Pearl Harbor on the chart.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...or 163 degrees. Browning traces a second line heading due south. Halsey's face wrinkles in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: For Christ sake... Pearl is under attack, and we don't even know if the bastards are north or south? Browning is accustomed to tough questions from his admira He taps a point near the southern line, unruffled.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Army bombers also reported a possible ship sighting here. Halsey stares at the spot. Then:

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: That's where we place our bet. What do we have left aboard?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROCKMAN
dialogues.text: Lindsey and his torpedo squadron.  16.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: What about dive bombers?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROCKMAN
dialogues.text: Most of them went into Pearl this morning, but we've got five left. The senior pilot is Dick Best. The XO of Bombing Six.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Good. That kid is full of piss and vinegar. (beat ) Launch everything we've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chalkboard identifies the squadron's planes and their operational status. Best and his four fellow dive bomber pilots sit on one side of the room wearing brown leather jackets. Eighteen torpedo bomber pilots sit on the other, dressed in olive drab flight suits with ties. LT. COMMANDER WADE MCCLUSKY, 39, delivers the briefing. H runs the air wing and is good friends with Best -- probab because they are both consummate professionals.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: We have a possible location on the Jap fleet, so we're launching a strike. Lindsey has command. McClusky looks at LT. EUGENE LINDSEY, 36, who sits in the front row. Lindsey commands Torpedo Six and is a bit of a dandy -- his men call him Errol Flynn behind his back. As Lindsey nods, McClusky traces a line on the giant map.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fly a grid on this bearing. If you make contact, Best and his men will put down a smokescreen and then the torpedo bombers will go in.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: The hell with smoke. Let me go after those carriers with a real bomb.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: Torpedoes sink carriers, not bombs. And my men need a screen. Best gives Lindsey a cold look.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: You need a screen because your planes are slow. And even if you get close enough, your torpedoes don't work. Most of the torpedo pilots bristle. But Lindsey shrugs.  17.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: That's a rumor.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: It's a rumor because the damn things have never even been tested. (to McClusky) The Japs are out there killing our friends. In a sneak attack. Let me put a 500-pound bomb right down their goddamned smokestack.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: You have your orders, lieutenant. Best is about to respond, but McClusky steps forward to q the disagreement.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: We're all frustrated. But we have to go by the book today. Best doesn't like it -- at all -- but he respects McClusk enough to stand down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best strides toward his waiting plane. He's intercepted b his radioman, JAMES MURRAY (25, danky) ; Murray has a lac North Carolina drawl, but the accent lies -- he's perpetu a bundle of raw nerves.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Are we going after the Japs, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're going to smoke ‘em to death. Best glances at Murray.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look like you're going to puke. The assessment is correct; Murray scared out of his mind the prospect of going out to find the Japanese fleet. But can't admit that to his pilot.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: I'm all right. (changing the subject) Any word from Mr. Dickinson?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Not yet.  18. Which means that his friend is likely dead. But Best just continues toward his plane; he has a job to do. The deck loudspeaker BLARES:

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Start engines!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one the 30-odd planes of the strike force rumble d the deck. The fighters and SBDs are nimble compared to th torpedo bombers, which struggle into the air -- slowed ev further by the one-ton torpedo strapped to their belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The planes are framed by the sunset. The SBDs do lazy hal circles to keep from outpacing the ponderous torpedo bomb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best scans the horizon, frustration etched in his express Murray's voice echoes through the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: See anything, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Not even a goddamned whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindsey is at the controls with his two CREWMEN behind hi He peers down ata map in his lap, but the fading sun has made it hard to decipher anything. Lindsey takes a deep breath and then speaks into his radi

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: Six baker ten, this is six torpedo one. Lead us back to Enterprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best stares at his radio, incredulous. He lifts the recei to his mouth and speaks with a clear edge.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Six torpedo ten, your pilots aren't trained for a night carrier landing with live ordinance. Go land at Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We can't clear the mountains. Take us back to Enterprise, lieutenant. That's a direct order. Best fumes for a long moment as_the pane 's engine drones the background. He finally toggles the intercom switch.  19.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Hey, Murray. Do we have a homing signal on the ZB? Murray glances down at a black box, which is showing a so red light. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: We're too far out.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Unbelievable. Best thinks for a moment and then toggles back to the rad

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Six torpedo one. I'm dropping my smoke bombs, turning on my running lights, and returning to Enterprise. Follow me if you want. Best yanks a lever and the plane lurches as the bombs rel Murray's nervous voice rings through the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do you know the way home, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: You better hope so. Because otherwise we're all going for a swim. We catch a glimpse of Murray's pale face in the back; he doesn't like the sound of that at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RADAR OFFICER peers into his rudimentary set as a smu of green lights appears at the edge of the scope.

dialogues.speaker: RADAR OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sir! Numerous bogies inbound.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Friendlies? The question hangs in the air -- the green dots on the sc reveal nothing. The RADIO OFFICER speaks into his set.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO OFFICER
dialogues.text: Incoming aircraft, identify yourself. Static crackles in response. Tension builds on the bridge Have the Japanese found them first? Are they about to suf the same fate as Pearl Harbor? Finally --

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is six baker ten. Requesting night landing. Everyone on the bridge breathes a deep sigh of relief.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LANDING SIGNAL OFFICER waves his green wands at the e of the illuminated flight deck. An SBD expertly catches t number one arresting wire and slams to a halt. The SBD taxies to the elevator, and Best swings out of th cockpit. McClusky emerges from the shadows to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: We got word from Pearl. The Jap fleet was north, not south. This is the cherry on the shit sundae for Best.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Those bastards in intelligence couldn't find their ass with two hands and a flashlight. WHAM! The next plane to land is a torpedo bomber. It hits the deck so hard that the deck vibrates. Even worse, the impact detaches the plane's torpedo. The deadly "fish" skids across the deck toward the ship's island, a thousand pounds of TNT connected to a percussiv cap. Halsey and his staff are about to be immolated. At the last moment a lone figure runs out of the darkness and leaps onto the deadly weapon. This is SLIM TOWNSEND, deck officer. He rides the torpedo like a bull, feet work as brakes, until it finally comes to a stop. As men rush to Slim's side to secure the torpedo, Best cr the deck in a cold fury. He marches up to Lindsey, who is smoking with a few of his pilots. Best jabs a finger at him.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You get yourself lost, expect me to bail you out, and now one of your men almost blows up the damn carrier because you were too chickenshit to fly into Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: I told you. We couldn't clear the --

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I know what you told me. But I bet you heard that Pearl is firing at everything in sight and were worried about your own ass.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: Do I have to remind you that I'm your superior officer?  21.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Don't hide behind your rank. At least pretend to be a goddamned man. Lindsey feels the eyes of his fellow pilots and feels obligated to step toward Best. But before it can escalate into a fight, McClusky runs up and shoves them apart.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! We're all frustrated. But save it for the Japs. Best stares past McClusky at Lindsey. Still seething.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: We're at war now, Lindsey. Get your shit together. And then Best turns on his heel and strides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral Kimmel sits at his desk, his head in his hands. L enters and closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: The Japanese are attacking on all fronts. Singapore, the Philippines, Guam, Thailand... No response from Kimmel. Layton forces himself to continu

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We captured a radio log from a downed Japanese plane. They hit us with all six of their fleet carriers. Kimmel looks up at Layton as if seeing him for the first time. He picks up a jagged piece of metal from the desk a holds it up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KIMMEL
dialogues.text: A spent .50 cal. It crashed through the window this afternoon and hit me square in the chest. Left a bruise. (beat ) I wish it had killed me. Layton has no idea what to do with this confession. He swallows hard. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KIMMEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're the best intelligence officer I've ever known, Layton. They'll probably burn you for this too, but if they don't... swear to me that you will make the next man in this chair listen to you. Because this can never happen again.  22. The words land hard on Layton; he already feels the immen weight of this failure. He draws himself up in a salute.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Enterprise enters the main channel. Her prow cuts thr water black with bunker oil, and smoke from the still-bur wreckage shrouds everything. Makeshift AA emplacements line the banks on either side o the channel. A SOLDIER shouts from the shore.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You better get the hell out of here or the Japs will nail you too! The words carry clearly across the water to Best and Moc Lusky, who are standing amid a group of men silently in evastation. Best is locked on the still-burning Arizona, eyes hollow. McClusky glances at him.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Think Cliff was aboard?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I don't know. He liked to sleep at home when he was in port.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: You were roommates at Annapolis?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Three years. And now he might be dead -- along with thousands of other good men. The duo stands in silence for a long moment. An then Best flicks his head up at the bridge behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at the old man. Halsey stands outside on the ying bridge, his jaw clenchi Hal y d id he flyi brid his j lenchi u ina rious rhythm as he takes in the scene. He finally turns to his flag officers, speaking to nobody in particu

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: I promise you... by the time we're through with them, the Japanese language will be spoken only in hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The still-burning Arizona casts a red glow on the scene a an oil tanker pumps fuel into the berthed Enterprise. Best strides down the gangway onto the wharf. When he see Dickinson waiting at the bottom, Best half-smiles with re  23. But then he straps on a poker face.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I heard that you jumped out of a perfectly good plane.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: It was on fire. And the controls were dead.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I would have landed it. (beat ) Where's Miller? Dickinson's expression answers him. Best's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, hell. They share a moment of pained silence for their fallen comrade. And then Dickinson points down the wharf.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Ann is over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Civilians stand behind a waist-high metal fence, overseen MPs. Best approaches from the other side, eyes searching crowd, until he locks eyes with ANN BEST, 28. She's a sha tongued firecracker who shares his Jersey accent. They rush to each other and embrace over the fence, holdi each other tightly. She whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Come home tonight. He pulls back, apologetic.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I wish. But we sail as soon as we're refueled. They don't want us in port until they're sure the Japs are gone.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I saw the first attack. Before I realized what was happening and got Barb down in the cellar. Dive bombers from the north.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Were they any good?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Not bad. But they didn't dive as steeply as your squadron. Best shakes his head, incredulous.  24.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: You're one hell of a Navy wife. Bombs falling and you keep your head. (beat) Any word from Cliff?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: He was on duty. We checked all of the hospitals, but nothing yet. The news is like a punch into Best's gut -- he knows that Cliff is likely dead. In the wake of that revelation the full weight of this awful day abruptly lands on him.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Goddammit ! Ann feels the anger and pain and frustration behind that ferocious word, and she takes her husband's hand. Her tou settles him, and Best takes a slow breath. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How's Sarah holding up?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: You know Sarah. Tough as nails. But... Yeah. They're silent for a moment, imagining themselves i Sarah's shoes. Best finally looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I want you and Barb to go back to your parents' place in Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: No. Best blinks, caught off-balance by her flat denial.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: It isn't safe here.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Everyone is saying this will be a long war, and I refuse to go years without seeing you. And neither will your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: But what if -- She cuts him off, tone firm.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: You're not shipping me off to Jersey. And that's final. Best stares at his wife, simultaneously frustrated by her obstinacy and impressed by her resolve. He finally nods.  25.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT addresses a joint session of Congress His nasally voice is braced with a steely resolve.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: Yesterday, December 7, 1941 -- a date which will live in infamy -- the United States of America was suddenly and deliberately attacked by the naval and air forces of Japan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traditional geisha houses line the street. Incongruously, broadcast of Roosevelt's speech echoes from an open windo

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The United States was at peace with that nation and still in conversation with its government for the maintenance of peace in the Pacific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yamamoto, now 56, sits at a tea table. He is naked except for a towel, revealing that he is in excellent shape for man his age. A radio broadcasts Roosevelt's words. A GEISHA sits across from Yamamoto, wearing a silk kimono

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No matter how long it may take us to overcome this premeditated invasion -- CLICK! Yamamoto twists the volume control of the radio. T geisha gives him a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: GEISHA
dialogues.text: What was the gaijin saying?

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Our ambassador in Washington failed to deliver our declaration of war on time. So the Americans think that Pearl Harbor was a sneak attack.

dialogues.speaker: GEISHA
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Yamamoto stands, his expression grim.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: It means that we have awakened a sleeping giant and filled him with terrible resolve.  26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brick and stone building looks as if it should be in London. Yamamoto emerges from his staff car, now resplend in his dress uniform. REAR ADMIRAL TAMON YAMAGUCHI, 49, a fiery and brilliant r star in the Imperial Navy, strides up to meet him. Yamamo is Tamon's mentor, and the two men share an understanding American culture -- Tamon studied at Princeton. But Tamon retains the bluntness of a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Did you enjoy your visit to Hawaii?

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: I told Nagumo that we needed to destroy the fuel tanks. But he refused to launch a third strike.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: That was a devastating mistake. It would have taken the Americans a year to resume operations at Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: When are you going to remove Nagumo from command?

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: How can I remove him? Nagano sunk the American battleships. Everyone thinks that he's a hero.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Someday that old fool will make an even bigger mistake. Yamamoto flicks his head at the General Headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: None of that talk inside. We must have a united front against the Army. Tamon gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: I'm not Nagumo. You don't have to instruct me in the obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two long tables face each other in the imposing room. Nav officers, marked by their blue uniforms, line one side. A officers, wearing brown, are on the other. PRIME MINISTER TOJO sits at a dais between them, wearing brown of the Army. His cold eyes are locked on Yamamoto, sits at the end of the naval table next to Tamon.  27.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Pearl Harbor was a great victory. But if we give them time, the Americans will overrun us. We therefore must land the knockout blow by destroying the rest of the American fleet. Tojo stares at Yamamoto, calculating. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: TOJO
dialogues.text: Our priority must be seizing the resources that we need, which is a job for the Army. The Navy's job is to get us there and back. Yamamoto disagrees with this theory down to the very core his soul. But he forces himself to stand and salute.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: So it shall be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yamamoto and Tamon ride in the back of a large sedan. Tam shakes his head, simmering.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: The Army got us into this war, and now they expect us to just ferry them around? Yamamoto shrugs, resigned to the situation.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: For now. But circumstances will change. Which is why I want you to start drawing up plans for the operation we discussed. Tamon's eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Midway. Yamamoto nods. The word hangs in the air as he stares out the window, once again lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Roosevelt signs a formal document at the desk, array of politicians behind him. Bulbs flash as mob of reporters and photographers jockey for prime position. As Roosevelt lifts his pen, SENATOR CONNALLY glances down at the watch that he is holding in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR CONNALLY
dialogues.text: As of 3:05 PM on December 11, 1941, the United States is officially at war with Germany.  28. Roosevelt and Connally awkwardly hold their pose as anoth round of bulbs pop. A REPORTER pushes his way forward to front of the scrum.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Mr. President! The Japs have us on the run, and people are worried that the West Coast is at risk. How is the Navy going to keep us safe? The panic in the reporter's voice infects most of the roo But not Roosevelt. He stares at the reporter.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT
dialogues.text: It's going to require strong leadership from Pearl. An admiral who can rebuild morale.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Do you have a candidate in mind? Roosevelt just smiles to himself, revealing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black sedan pulls up in front of the utilitarian Main N Building. ADMIRAL CHESTER NIMITZ, 59, emerges wearing his dress uniform. He is tall with patrician features and pie blue eyes that accurately forecast his ferocious intellig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SECRETARY ushers Nimitz through a bustling main office. She opens a door marked: "Admiral Ernest King, COMINCH."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ADMIRAL KING, 63, stands with his back to us, clutching a phone. The enormous office contains just a card table and two folding chairs. The secretary glances at Nimitz.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Don't mind the office, Admiral. It's a work in progress.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Like our fleet. The secretary smiles and exits, closing the door behind h King growls into the phone -- as Roosevelt himself once s "he's a man who shaves with a blowtorch."

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KING
dialogues.text: I need an answer today, dammit. The phone slams back onto its receiver. King turns toward Nimitz, who greets him with a salute.  29.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Congratulations, sir. You were the right choice for commander -in-chief of the Navy.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KING
dialogues.text: When they get in trouble, they send for the sons of bitches. (beat) Sorry about the Arizona. She was your flagship, wasn't she?

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Yes. A lot of good men on that ship. We hear the pain in Nimitz's tone: he's lost countless friends. King waves at the folding chairs. As they sit --

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KING
dialogues.text: The situation in the Pacific is even worse than has been reported. We have three carriers, the Japs have ten. We have zero functional battleships, they have nine. They have more cruisers, more bombers, more fighters, and much of their equipment is more modern.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Can we shift resources from the Atlantic?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KING
dialogues.text: The President has decided that Germany must be the priority of the war effort. If England and Russia fall... The enormity of the challenge weighs on both men. Finally

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It will take at least a year to build new ships and train more men. In the meantime we'll just have to count on the boys we have to hold the line.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I don't envy the new commander. King stares at him, flat. Nimitz does the math.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's me, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KING
dialogues.text: The President asked for you himself. He said that you should get the hell out to Pearl and stay there until our ships sail into Tokyo Bay. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL KING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat ) Welcome to the most difficult job in the world. We go CLOSE on Nimitz as he processes the words. This is greatest opportunity -- and responsibility -- of his life

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crumpled remains of the Arizona jut out of the water, surrounded by a vast oil slick. A grim crew of sailors on the deck are carefully removing incinerated human remains and placing them into canvas bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group has gathered on the nearby shore of the harbor fo funeral. A large photo of an officer in his white dress uniform reveals that the honoree is Cliff Janz. Cliff's wife SARAH, 28, lays a wreath of flowers in the w She stares at the wreck of the Arizona -- just a few hund yards away -- as a bugler PLAYS "Taps." Behind Sarah is a row of Naval officers in their dress uniforms along with their wives and families. Best holds hands with Ann, his jaw working furiously as he tries to contain his grief. Sarah's two young sons are next to Cliff's photo, doing t best to be brave. But one begins to cry, and Ann steps fo and puts an arm around him. We PAN to reveal that several other ceremonies are being conducted further down the shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best, Ann and Sarah stand next to a Ford V-8 as Sarah's t sons wait patiently in the back seat. Sarah's eyes flicker to the wreck of the Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It's just so empty. We don't even have a body to bury. Best can't find the words to respond. Ann finally says...

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I know. Sarah locks on Best.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Cliff wanted to be a pilot like you, but I talked him out of it. I said it was too dangerous.  31. Sarah shakes her head, caught by the cruel irony, and the opens her car door.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll see you at the next funeral. I think we have two more today and three tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: You don't have to go. Sarah sets her jaw, finding some bastion of inner strengt

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yes I do. We're family. Ann and Best just nod; they know exactly what Sarah means The Navy takes care of its own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas decorations incongruously hang amid military memorabilia and tiki kitsch. Naval officers in their dres uniforms pack the narrow space from end-to-end. The photo Cliff hangs in a position of honor over the bar. Best, Dickinson and McClusky huddle in a corner, obviousl several drinks deep. McClusky finishes his beer. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Did you hear? Wake Island fell. Best shakes his head, morose.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Four hundred and fifty Marines hold out against a whole Jap invasion force for fifteen days and the Navy just leaves them there to die.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Washington was probably worried about losing the rest of the fleet.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: We can't win this war if they don't let us fight. DING! The bell behind the bar rings. JIMMY THATCH, 36, st on a chair to deliver a toast. He's an icy-cool fighter p with a distinctive Arkansas drawl.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: I just want to say that Cliff Janz was one of the finest bastards I've ever met. I could talk about the man for an hour, but I think that's a job for one of you boys who went to the Academy with him.  32. Heads swivel, searching for a candidate. Best turns to Dickinson, but Dickinson waves him off, eyes already wet. chokes out the words:

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: I can't. And so Best clambers onto the bar and turns to the sea of faces. Best hates public speaking, but he'll be damned if nobody eulogizes his friend. Best gestures at Thatch.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Well, hell... I can't let some fighter jockey speak for Cliff. Especially one not good enough to fly from Enterprise. Thatch smiles at the jab as men from other ships good- naturedly boo. Best holds up his hands for silence.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Summer after plebe year me and Cliff went up to visit his uncle on the Great Lakes. It's the peak of Prohibition, and we decide to sail to Canada in the dead of night to buy some beer. We get the beer all right, but on our way back -- right before the sun comes up -- the wind dies. Best pauses for a moment, lost in the memory.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There we are, floating in the middle of the lake, just waiting for the Border Patrol to show up. I say we should ditch the booze. But Cliff says, ‘Hell no. We'll drink it all.' When those officers found us, we were rolling. The group hoots in appreciation. But Best's expression ch like a dark cloud passing in front of the sun.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cliff loved to laugh -- and he never seemed to break a sweat -- but if you dug deep there was something else. I don't know what happened aboard the Arizona, but I guarantee Cliff went down fighting. (beat) Cliff was my roommate, my best man, the godfather to my daughter. I thought that someday we'd be drinking beer on a porch and telling lies about what we did in the big war.  33. For a painful moment Best gets lost in his emotions. But then he grabs a shot glass from the bar and holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To Cliff! May you get to Heaven before the Devil knows you're dead. The group roars, the sound deafening in the small bar, an then everyone downs their shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best, McClusky and Dickinson weave down the wharf toward looming shape of the Enterprise, their faces flushed with alcohol. Dickinson pauses, eyes locked on something.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Shit. Shore patrol. A small convoy of jeeps is streaking toward them, flags f from the hoods. Best squints.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Nah, that's an Admiral's flag. I bet it's the new commander.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Who do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I don't care if it's Gengis Khan if he'll let us fight. The jeeps speed closer. A figure with shock of white hair sitting ramrod straight in the back of the lead vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Looks like Nimitz. The men nod appreciatively; this is good news.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: At least they sent the A-team. (shouting) Hey, Nimitz! Let us at those Japs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words carry over the Jeep's engine. As Nimitz turns h head toward the three officers walking on the wharf, a horrified STAFF OFFICER leans toward his new commander.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir. Do you want me to go get their names? Nimitz shakes his head, a thin smile on his face.  34.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: We've taken a hell of a wallop. I'm glad that at least some of the boys still want to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant map of the Pacific Theater dominates one wall. Ni sits behind a large desk, flipping through a stack of fil Layton enters and gives him a stiff salute.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Welcome to Pearl, sir. I'm Lieutenant Commander Layton. Nimitz glances up from his work.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Then you'll understand my request. I wish to be reassigned to a destroyer.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: You can kill more Japs here with me than you'll ever kill on a destroyer. Layton blinks. He wasn't expecting that response.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: You want me on your staff?

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Didn't you try to warn my predecessor about the impending attack?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Not exactly. I said that we had lost track of the enemy carriers and needed to be prepared.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: But Admiral Kimmel didn't take you seriously because Washington disagreed.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I should have pushed harder.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: A lesson, I assume, that you have taken to heart.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm the intelligence officer responsible for overseeing the greatest intelligence failure in American history. It will look bad if you keep me.  35. Nimitz gives Layton a long look. Then:

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Close the door. Layton complies. Nimitz stands and comes around the desk.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Morale is low -- and for good reason. The Philippines are soon to fall, and the Japanese are advancing on all fronts at a terrifying pace. Even worse, meaningful reinforcements won't arrive for at least another year. I nevertheless believe that we can hold the line. I know the fighting spirit of our men, and I have faith in them. (beat) But I also need to know that they have faith in themselves. Layton chews over the words for a long moment; he underst exactly what Nimitz is asking him. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I knew what the Japanese were going to do, but I didn't push hard enough. I won't make that mistake again. Nimitz nods, the question settled.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Then you will be my Admiral Yamamoto. Get in his head, tell me what he's going to do next. Nimitz walks over to the giant map, Layton trailing him.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here's my first assignment. We need to throw a punch. Not just for morale, but so that the Japanese know what it feels like to be hit. Nimitz's finger circles a desolate cluster of islands squ in the center of the Pacific.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sending Halsey and the Enterprise to hit the Marshall Islands. But I need to know that they aren't walking into a trap. Layton starts toward the door; he understands the assignm

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I'll locate the enemy carriers.  36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great ship churns through the Pacific, leaving a translucent green wake behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McClusky stands at the front of the room, delivering the briefing to the assembled pilots.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: The target is Roi Island. Our submarines have reported shipping traffic and a military airfield. Although we have the advantage of surprise, we don't know exactly what we're facing. So hit them as hard as possible and then get the hell out.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: What about the enemy carriers?

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Intelligence says they're two thousand miles away. Best raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: The same group of geniuses who blew Pearl Harbor?

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Like I said... be prepared for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonlight illuminates the rows of tightly-packed planes. Best strides up to his SBD where Murray waits, practicall vibrating with nervous energy.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Morning, sir. What's the plan?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: The other squadrons will hit first. We'll go in last to clean up the remaining targets.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Meaning the Japs are going to be ready for us. (Best shrugs) What if we're shot down? Murray is clearly jooking for reassurance from his pilot. Best jerks a finger at the SBD's twin Brownings.  37.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I'm not going to be a POW, so your job is to get those .30 cals to me. We'll put our backs into a sand dune and keep shooting until they have to kill us to get the damn guns. Murray's knees weaken -- this is not the morale boost he needed. But Best just swings up into the cockpit, oblivio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindsey flies low, the waves just fifty feet beneath the belly of his plane. His eyes are locked on a dozen ships tightly clustered in a narrow anchorage.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: (into radio) I've got the heavy cruiser in my sights. Pick a target and get close enough to make them count. Tracers abruptly streak out toward the planes from either side of the anchorage. Lindsey yanks a lever... ...and his TBD lurches as the one-ton torpedo splashes in the water below. Lindsey immediately banks away from the gunfire. The torpedo, meanwhile, bubbles toward --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panicked sailors shout in Japanese on the deck of the lig armed ship. The engines rumble to a start as men furiousl work to slip the anchor, but the ship remains a sitting d At the last moment the men brace for impact -- THUD! The torpedo slams into the hull and breaks in half. The stunned sailors pick themselves off the deck and glan over the side where the broken pieces of the weapon bob a innocently as buoys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rising sun on the horizon matches the Japanese flag f over the base. A siren BLARES a warning as a line of Type fighters hurtle themselves into the air. At the last moment we catch a glimpse of a diving aircraf it's an SBD. Bombs drop from the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickinson stares at a series of distant explosions throug pair of binoculars. The sprawling archipelago of the Mars Islands is visible below him, partially concealed by clou

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Looks like our boys on Roi poked a hornet's nest.  38. Dickinson swings the binoculars. A fast-moving cloud pass ahead of him, revealing another Japanese airfield in the center of a large island. Dozens of planes Tine the runwa

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. Dickinson fumbles to toggle the switch on his radio.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've got a problem. I have eyes on a second enemy airfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best flies above a cloud, the five other planes of his scouting squadron trailing off his right wing.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I'm counting maybe thirty bombers. And heavy fighter cover.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Copy that. (he flips the channel) You hear that, boys? If we don't knock out that airfield, they'll go after Enterprise. And I want a place to land when this is over. Best shoves his throttle forward.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stay on my wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reports pour in from the radio as Captain Browning marks estimated positions of the various air groups on the map. Halsey enters and locks on Browning.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: What have we got?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: The Roi airfield is out of commission. Our torpedo bombers are going after some ships in the harbor. (beat ) But there's another major airfield on Taroa. At least thirty bombers. Halsey blanches. This is not good news.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Can we hit it?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Best and his scouts are en route. But they've got no fighter cover.  39. Halsey's expression is clear: that's nowhere near enough planes to do the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taroa Island is quickly approaching. Metal glints off the left wingtip of Best's SBD, catching Murray's attention. frantically shouts into his intercom.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Enemy fighters, sir. Nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: (into radio) We got company. Start your runs. Best shoves the throttle forward and then drops the SBD's nose. As the plane accelerates, flak bursts in the sky ah of them. The percussion wave rattles the airframe. Best ignores the flak and rolls the SBD onto its back. An instant later they're plummeting downwards at the plane's terminal velocity -- almost three hundred miles an hour. Murray clutches the handles in the back seat, floating ag his harness as he goes weightless. His panicked eyes are focused on the altimeter, which is spinning downward. Ten thousand feet... eight thousand feet... Best peers into the three-powered telescope above the instrument panel, one hand on the stick and the other on bomb release. Murray's voice echoes in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Three thousand... two thousand... Best yanks the bomb release, and the plane lurches as fiv hundred pounds fall away. He pulls the stick -- -- and is slammed back into his seat as the immense weigh of six Gs slam into his torso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anti-aircraft emplacement spits shells into the face o Best's oncoming SBD. The air SCREAMS as the plane pulls o of its dive, just a hundred feet off the ground. BOOM! The largest hanger explodes as Best's bomb detonate shredding a dozen Japanese bombers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best works the stick, blinking the haze from his eyes. A fighter appears in the windscreen, and Best steers straig at it. He lines up his gunsight and depresses the trigger  40. RAT-TAT-TAT! The SBD vibrates with the shots. The muzzle the Japanese plane is also flashing, and we WHIP PAN as i passes us at 500 miles an hour. Best glances over his shoulder and sees black smoke burst from the enemy fighter's wing. But he has no time to cele because two other fighters are closing from six o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Get those bastards off me. Murray opens fire as Best weaves and bobs, trying to stay out of their gunsights. But the fighters keep closing unt THUD! THUD! Bullets slam into the SBD. Murray instinctive drops the guns and takes cover.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep firing, dammit! It takes an enormous effort, but Murray forces himself to return to the guns. As they chatter back into action, the second enemy fighter begins its pass... ...but Best pulls back on the stick and the SBD rises int massive cumulus cloud. Suddenly, the world is white. Murr nervously peers from side to side until -- -- they pop back out into the brilliant blue. Murray lock on an object off the right wing.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Bogey! Three o'clock. The SBD ducks back into the clouds. Ten claustrophobic se pass. And then they emerge back into the sunlight... Murray pans from side to side. Nothing. But just as he breathes a sigh of relief, he notices a plume spewing fro their right wing.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting) Mr. Best, we're on fire! Best turns to look. And then he shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Damn it, Murray, that's just gasoline. Don't scare me like that again. Murray's face says, just gasoline? And then he sinks back into his seat, utterly drained from his baptism by fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best's SBD taxies to a halt. Dickinson is waiting for Bes as he emerges from the cockpit.  41.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: We got most of those bombers. But not all of 'em. Dickinson gives the damaged wing a dry glance.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Looks like they almost got you. Best fingers one of the holes made by the Japanese rounds and then shrugs, unfazed.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Not enough lead. Murray, on the other hand, gives the damage a horrified l as he registers exactly how close they came to the edge. Dickinson's radioman, BRUNO GAIDO, 24, sidles up to him. Bruno is short with a heavy Long Island accent.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: You're lucky to fly with Best.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Want to trade?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: What? Too much excitement for you?

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's trying to win the war all by himself. Bruno is about to respond, but an air raid siren abruptly BLARES. Best and Dickinson share a glance.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: That can't be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halsey paces behind the radar officer, who is staring int his scope like a crystal ball.

dialogues.speaker: RADAR OFFICER
dialogues.text: We have multiple bogies. About fifteen miles out and closing fast.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO OFFICER
dialogues.text: Fighting Six en route to intercept. A burst of STATIC from the radio. Then --

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: This is Six Foxtrot One. We have visual on five twin-engine bombers. Stand by to intercept. Ten seconds of silence. Tension swells on the bridge. And then an explosion of noise from the radio.  42.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Guns jammed! Guns jammed! (another voice) Dammit to hell. Me too. (the first voice) Enterprise, this is Six Foxtrot One. Intercept failed. Everyone looks to Halsey. He stands ramrod straight, seem unfazed by the news.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: We'll do it the old fashioned way. Fire with everything we've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the gun emplacements on either side of the deck swing into action, the ships escorting the Enterprise also open fire. Clouds of flak burst off the stern in an ominous st Dickinson and Best remain standing on the deck, watching with a professional detachment as five Japanese Type 96 ("Nell") bombers race toward the carrier. The flak is bursting far behind the incoming aircraft, an Dickinson shakes his head, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Goddamned gunners... don't they know they've gotta lead those planes?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: They're too excited. They've never fired at a live target before. (beat) Might as well be using water pistols. The Nells are now just a thousand yards away -- close eno to see their bomb bay doors opening.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Brace for impact. The men crouch against the deck as bombs fall from the pl The Japanese have the Enterprise dead to rights... ...but the deck lurches as the helmsman swings the wheel. This is a twenty-thousand ton ship moving at thirty knots but she is nevertheless surprisingly agile. Best stares up at the bombs, calculating. The first ones slam into the water a hundred yards to starboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam hisses as the giant turbines whirl. A giant BOSUN bellows amid the noise.  43.

dialogues.speaker: BOSUN
dialogues.text: Flank speed! THUD! THUD! The force of the bombs detonating in the wate slams into the hull like a giant hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final bomb explodes just fifty feet off the starboard bow, showering the deck with water. Halsey watches the bo as they pass over the ship and then turns to his officers

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Tell the helmsmen that was damn good steering. Browning points out the window.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: It isn't over. Four of the bombers are streaking away from the carrier, one is turning around and coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best and Dickinson stare at the incoming bomber. It's rap dropping altitude, nose pointed at the ship.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: What the hell is he doing?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Turning himself into a bomb. The bomber is approaching directly from the stern, and mo of the Enterprise's AA guns are therefore unable to train it. Best helplessly watches the bomber, doing the math, u a lone figure dashes across the deck. It's Bruno Gaido. He runs to the aftmost parked SBD, leap into the rear séat, and racks the .30 cals. An instant la he opens fire in the face of the oncoming bomber. The Japanese pilot adjusts his course so that he's coming straight toward Bruno. It's an old-fashioned duel: mano a mano. Bruno keeps firing, unflinching, until -- -- the bomber's wing abruptly bursts into flame. But the Japanese pilot ignores it and fights to hold his course. Best and Dickinson watch in horror as the bomber's wing s through Bruno's SBD -- cutting it in half -- before the Japanese plane skids over the deck and slams into the oce The rear half of the SBD does a 360, sliding with a scree toward the sea, but it miraculously grinds to a halt just feet from the edge of the deck.  44. RAT-TAT-TAT! The .30 cals are still firing. Bruno stands his tiptoes and hammers more bullets into the sinking pla When it finally disappears beneath the waves, he calmly f the safety on the .30 cals and then swings out onto the d Dickinson and Best are rushing up to the plane along with the fire crew. As they spray the SBD with water, Dickinso stares at Bruno and shakes his head, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Damn, Bruno. Bruno just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Ain't they paying us to kill Japs? Before Dickinson can reply, a breathless ENSIGN runs up t the group. He points at Bruno.

dialogues.speaker: ENSIGN
dialogues.text: Admiral Halsey wants to see you on the bridge. Bruno blanches. He might have had no qualms about facing down a Japanese bomber, but being called up to the bridge a whole different ballgame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ensign enters, Bruno warily trailing behind him. Hals turns away from a chart and locks on Bruno.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: That's the bravest damn thing I've ever seen. What's your name, son? Bruno draws himself up in his best salute.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Bruno Gaido, sir. Aviation Machinist's Mate Third Class.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Well, Bruno... you are now an Aviation Machinist's Mate First Class. As Bruno breaks into a smile, Browning catches Halsey's e

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Admiral, don't you think it's about time we got the hell out of here?

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: I was thinking the same thing myself. Halsey turns to the radioman.  45.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Signal the fleet. Tell them it's time to haul ass with Halsey. As the radioman moves to comply, Big Band music incongruo begins to PLAY in the background.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The sprawling compound, known from its paint color as the "Pink Palace," overlooks Waikiki Beach. Palm trees sway i the breeze -- it feels a million miles away from the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Navy has taken over the hotel. Officers in uniform st in the front door, along with young women wearing USO pin A well-worn Ford parks, and Best gets out of the car. He holds the door open for Ann. As she emerges, she gives a passing gaggle of USO women a dry look.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Are you sure that you want your wife flying wingman for you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Nobody told me there were going to be USO girls. So if you wouldn't mind letting me do a quick lap by myself... Ann gives his arm a condescending pat.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: That's cute. But we both know you can barely handle the woman you have. Best smiles and then takes Ann's arm and leads her toward the hotel's entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Western-themed restaurant is packed with revelers. Se members surreptitiously sip from flasks as couples whirl the dance floor in front of a Navy band. Best sits with his arm around Ann at a table across from Dickinson and McClusky. Dickinson is midway through a sto

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: So my dad takes the turn too hard, and I literally fall off the back of the turnip truck.
