The next thing I know this girl is -- A burst of CHEERING from the corner interrupts the story: it's a group of torpedo bombers and USO women. Lindsey st at the center of the circle, basking in attention.  46.

dialogues.speaker: TORPEDO BOMBER
dialogues.text: We showed those Japs! As the group cheers again, Best rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Look at those yahoos. We faced the Jap's B-team, and they still gave us all we could handle.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Maybe. But a win's a win. Why not enjoy the moment? Best considers the words and then glances down at Ann's e glass. He squeezes her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Want another drink?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I do if you want me to dance. Best smiles and heads toward the bar. When he's gone, McC leans across the table toward Ann.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: You should be proud of your man. He was a rock out there.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Why isn't he commanding the squadron? McClusky blinks at her bluntness -- amusing Dickinson, wh is more familiar with Ann's style.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: I don't make those decisions.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I understood before the war when everything was about politics. But now? He's the best pilot in the fleet.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: There's an old saying in the Navy. The best pilots don't make the best commanders.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Dickinson and McClusky stare at Ann, weighing her. Dickin eventually decides to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Your husband expects everyone to be as good as he is. And he has no patience when we aren't. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But real leadership comes from understanding what makes the rest of us tick. Ann absorbs the words and then glances across the bar at Best, who is still waiting for his drinks. As he reaches his wallet, a man bellies up to the bar next to him. It's Layton. He glances at the patch on Best's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: You're a dive bomber on Enterprise? Best nods, eyes locked on the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Can I buy you a round? Best swings his head to look at Layton. He immediately lo on the insignia attached to his collar.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Fleet Intelligence, huh? (beat) Maybe you guys should spend less time drinking and more time trying to find the Japs. Best's tone is flat, but there's no mistaking the insult. Layton flushes.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: This is my first time out since Pearl. Me and my team are trying to win this war, just like you flyboys.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Yeah, and every time I see the wreck of the Arizona I think about what a bang-up job you're doing. At that moment the bartender returns with the drinks. Bes slaps a five-dollar bill on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep the change, buddy. Best grabs the drinks and strides back to his table, leav a stunned Layton in his wake. He puts the glasses down in front of the group and offers Ann his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's dance.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party continues as Best and Ann slowly swirl on the d floor, her head on his shoulder. For this one moment they are just a young couple in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light from the hallway illuminates a child's bedroom. Bes crouches on the floor, watching BARBERA BEST, 4, sleep. S clutches a teddy bear clad in a Naval Academy football je The door opens slightly, revealing Ann wearing a bathrobe

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Come to bed. Best gently smooths Barb's covers and kisses her forehead And then, after one reluctant last look, he leaves the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz comes around his desk to greet Halsey, hand outstretched. As they shake --

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Hell of a job, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Well, I got the boys' feet wet. But I might have pushed my luck a little bit at the end.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: We aren't going to get back in this war without taking a few chances. (beat ) In that spirit there's someone who I want you to meet. Nimitz nods at the corner of the room, and JIMMY DOOLITTL 45, steps forward. He wears a leather bomber jacket and - like Halsey -- has an infectious swagger.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Lieutenant Colonel Doolittle from the Army Air Force. He wants to bomb Tokyo. Halsey gives Doolittle a dubious look.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: So do I. But there's the small matter of fighting through the entire Japanese navy first.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That's why I want to launch my B-25s from one of your carriers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have the range to strike from outside the Japanese defenses. Halsey blinks, not quite sure that he heard Doolittle rig e and then glances at Nimitz.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: He's out of his goddamned mind.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: They say the same thing about you. Are you willing to try and get him within 500 miles of Japan?

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: If some Army flyboy has the guts to launch a fifteen ton aircraft from a carrier, I don't see how the Navy can say no. Nimitz nods, decision made.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Then you gentlemen are partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enterprise sorties into the open ocean. Hornet trails beh her, sixteen B-25Bs strapped to her flight deck. The plan look outlandishly large on the carrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five young pilots shift nervously in their seats. Best abruptly bursts into the room and launches into a speech without so much as clearing his throat.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard Enterprise. You're replacing good men -- much earlier than either me or the Navy wanted. But that's war. (beat) Questions? The men blink, overwhelmed. WILLIE WEST, 24, finally stic his hand in the air. Willie is athletic and unrelentingly earnest -- an all-American in the old sense of the phrase

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I saw the bombers on the deck of the Hornet. Where are we going, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: The destination of this task force is Tokyo.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Tokyo?  50. Best stares at Willie, reading his nerves and naivete. Af an uncomfortable moment --

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: As XO it's my job to make sure you're worth more than a bucket of warm spit, and I don't have time to coddle you. The Japs are waiting for us, so we need pilots who can hold their own. Best starts toward the door. He speaks over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll hold your qualifying landings as soon as we launch those bombers. I need you in the rotation ASAP, so don't screw it up. And then he's gone. The five young pilots stare at each o eyes wide. Last week they were in flight school; today th in the middle of the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enterprise and Hornet steam due west, surrounded by a rin of cruisers and destroyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halsey stands in the center of the bridge, reading a mess He glances up at his officers.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Enemy pickets five miles out. They're going to blow our cover.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Should we tell Doolittle to launch?

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Every mile we get him closer to Tokyo is fuel he can use to get the hell out of there. But... Halsey's face reflects his dilemma: he also has to worry about his own men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The B-25Bs are parked impossibly close together on the de Army crews scramble to get into the planes as the cruiser USS Nashville fires her main battery in the background. The heavy retort of the guns carries to Jimmy Thatch, who watching the scene with GEORGE GAY, 26. Gay is a torpedo bomber with a blue-collar edge and a thick Texas twang.  51.

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: Jesus. You ever seen a cruiser fire before?

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Not at a live target. Gay turns his attention to the B-25Bs. Doolittle is clamb into the lead bomber.

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: They might be Army, but they've got some balls on them. (beat ) Ten bucks they don't get those planes off the deck.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: I'll take that bet. The twin engines of Doolittle's B-25B roar into action an the bomber lurches forward. It's an impossibly short amou of runway for the huge plane, and when it reaches the end the deck it drops toward the waiting sea... ...but its wings claw for air, engines screaming, and the plane recovers just above the crest of the waves. As it c into the sky, the next B-25B starts down the deck. Thatch breathes a sigh of relief and then looks at Gay, w has a similar expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: That's ten bucks I'm glad to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz paces as his flag officers stare down at a giant m Layton and Rochefort, meanwhile, are huddled over a long- range radio set in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Shouldn't the bombers have reached Japan by now? Rochefort twists a dial and the radio locks on a station. seductive female voice speaks English with a Japanese acc This is the notorious propagandist TOKYO ROSE.

dialogues.speaker: TOKYO ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Radio Tokyo. Everyone is talking about the collapse of American forces in the Philippines and the capture of thousands of their imperialist troops. Very soon our -- Tokyo Rose's voice abruptly ceases, followed by the faint wail of an AIR RAID SIREN. Nimitz leans toward the radio, trying to hear through the static.  52.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Is that what I think it is? A burst of SHOUTING in Japanese comes through the radio. Everyone looks at Layton.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are they saying? Layton listens for a moment. And then a thin smile.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: They're under attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Layton emerges from his well-worn Ford Deluxe and walks u the driveway to his front door, briefcase under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Layton puts his briefcase on the table and pulls out a th sheaf of papers. As he begins to sort through them, Miria appears in the doorway, wearing a nightgown. She gives La a long look, noting his haggard expression.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Come to bed. You look like something the cat spat up.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I'll be right there. Miriam crosses the room and removes his glasses. Layton blinks; he's blind as a bat without them.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I'm taking these hostage.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Just half an hour. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Does America winning the war really depend on Edwin Layton working himself to death? Layton weighs her words for a long moment. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Some of our boys bombed Tokyo today. They were supposed to land in Free China, but they ran out of fuel and had to bail out over Japanese occupied territory. If the Japs catch them, they'll be tortured and executed. Miriam blinks, shocked at both the news and the fact that her husband shared the information.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What can you do to help them?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Probably nothing. But we're not going to lose any more men because I didn't dig deep or push hard enough. Layton says it without affect, but Miriam can nevertheles hear the pain behind the words. She carefully slides the glasses back onto his face and starts toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I'll fix you a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Japanese soldiers cluster around a crashed B-25B, staring the American insignia painted on its wings and tail. An officer TALKS into a radio, his tone insistent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doolittle sits against a wall, bandaging a badly-sprained ankle. A dog trots inside. It growls when it notices him.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hey, beat it. The dog responds by bursting into a fit of barking. A mom later Doolittle hears VOICES outside the door. He looks f another exit, but he's trapped. Doolittle draws his service revolver and checks the actio But his expression is conflicted as he stares down at the gun. Is he really going to use it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of Chinese men hurry a limping Doolittle past gaw peasants. They lead him through a door into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cramped room is packed with more peasants. Doolittle locks on a familiar face: COLE (his co-pilot) is standing between a pair of burly men in the corner. As the two Americans exchange a worried glance, ZHU XUESA 33, enters. The peasants give him a nod of respect. He lo at Doolittle and speaks in accented English.

dialogues.speaker: ZHU
dialogues.text: Who are you? Doolittle briefly hesitates before squaring his shoulders

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: American pilots. We crashed here after bombing Japan.  54. Zhu processes the words and then turns and speaks to the rest of the group in Chinese. Doolittle tries to read the reaction, but for an anxious moment they're stone-faced.. ...and then they turn to him and begin to smile and bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Japanese armored car rushes down the center of a dirt r It makes no effort to swerve around an ox-drawn hay wagon and the ancient-looking vehicle is forced into a ditch. As the dust recedes we reveal that the "farmer" calming t ox is actually Zhu. We PAN back to reveal two faces peeri out from beneath the hay: Cole and Doolittle. Cole glance from the retreating armored car to Zhu.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Why are they helping us?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: If you think Pearl Harbor was bad, you should have seen what the Japs did to Nanking. The wagon wheels squeak as the ox once again lumbers forw Zhu waits until they're back on the road and then speaks the Americans out of the corner of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ZHU
dialogues.text: Tonight we will cross the lines. You will be safe by morning. Yes? Doolittle and Cole glance at each other, grateful for the unexpected saviors. All they can say is...

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seven giant battleships that form the traditional hea of the Japanese fleet lie at anchor. The largest of them is Yamato, the most powerful warship ever built.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon steps aboard the ship, ignoring the salutes froma line of midshipmen. Men are still welding on the deck -- Yamato is a month away from being declared operational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon marches down a long corridor and then stops in fron of a watertight door marked with an admiral's crest. He t a breath before he knocks and enters --  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dim light reveals that the spacious suite is filled w an unusual blend of objects: framed degrees from Harvard Oxford next to samurai swords. Yamamoto sits on a mat in the corner, legs crossed. He sp without looking at his guest.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Leave me.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: You must come out of your cabin. It's bad for morale. Yamamoto slowly turns his head. His eyes are hollow.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: The Emperor was in Tokyo during the raid. We put his life at risk.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: It was a handful of bombers.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: We swore to keep our homeland impenetrable, so even a bungling attack is better than the most skillful defense. Tamon hears the agony in Yamamoto's voice. He crosses the room and crouches next to his commander.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: I came from Tokyo. Everyone now agrees that you were right about the American carriers. They must be destroyed. Yamamoto stares at Tamon, a spark lighting in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: They approved my Midway plan?

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Tojo says we must finish our operation in the Coral Sea. But then we can turn our attention to Midway. Yamamoto unfolds his legs and stands.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Then we have work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickinson and Best stand amid a group of pilots and radio in the brilliant sunshine. Best holds a clipboard, his ey locked on a SBD approaching the carrier.  56. The pilot has taken too shallow an approach for his landi but he manages to correct and grabs the middle wire. Best nods to himself and then marks the clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Not bad. We'll put him in the rotation. (to Dickinson) Who's next to qualify?

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Willie West. Best locks on a lone figure walking out to an idling plan

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Where's his radioman?

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: He couldn't find anyone willing to fly with him. (off Best) They could smell his fear. First time you land on this deck, it looks like a postage stamp. And nobody wants to get wet. Best is clearly unhappy with the situation, but before he respond Bruno Gaido steps forward from the group of radio

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: I'll go with him. Everyone stares at Bruno; to the other radiomen this seem like madness. But Bruno just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He shouldn't fly alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone SBD approaches the Enterprise, skewing awkwardly i the air as the pilot makes constant micro-adjustments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie clutches the stick in a death grip, eyes locked on the carrier's deck. Bruno growls from the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Breathe, goddammit. The words help; Willie slightly relaxes his grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SBD comes in like a wounded duck. It appears that it might overshoot the carrier entirely, but at the last mom it dips toward the deck. The wheels slam into the wood an the hook miraculously catches the final wire.  57. Best and Dickinson share an incredulous glance.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I guess he passed.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: By an act of god.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Maybe. But we need him in the rotation. (off Dickinson) How else is he going to learn? Dickinson doesn't like it, but he knows there's truth beh Best's words. They need every pilot they can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only been five months since the attack, but most of damage has been repaired and new buildings have arisen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz stares out the window at the harbor, brow furrowed he thinks. He finally turns back to the room, revealing - -- Rochefort and Layton standing in front of the tactical map. The position of two US carrier task forces are clear marked: Lexington and Yorktown are in the South Pacific a Enterprise is halfway between them and Pearl Harbor.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: So the Japanese are sending two carriers into the Coral Sea? Layton's hand sweeps across a handful of islands.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: They're trying to break our lifeline to Australia. And if they succeed... We'll be screwed. Nimitz nods to himself.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Then Lexington and Yorktown are in the right spot. I'll order Enterprise to join them. Rochefort realizes they've been dismissed and starts for door. But Layton grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Tell him about the other thing.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: It's just a theory.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: What kind of theory?  58. Rochefort doesn't like being called on the carpet, especi in front of his admiral. But he reluctantly explains.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: The Japanese are planning something bigger. Much bigger.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: What makes you think that?

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: Little bits and pieces that we've intercepted. A message that a battleship won't be ready in time for an upcoming operation. A request for maps of the Aleutians Islands. Orders for large quantities of refueling hoses.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Where are they going to hit?

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: We don't know yet.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Well, figure it out. Nimitz means it as a joke, but Rochefort takes him at fac value. He salutes and then exits. Layton, however, linger

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I trust his instincts.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I hope so. Because I'm betting on them. Nimitz stares down at the two carriers in the South Pacif

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, we finally might be facing decent odds. Especially if Enterprise gets down there in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amid the picturesque turquoise waters a carrier burns, a thick plume of oily black smoke rising into the sky. "Lexington" is painted across her stern.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: KABOOM! Aviation fuel ignites, sending the Lexington's re elevator soaring into the sky. This ship is finished.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Two enemy carriers supposedly wounded. But at the price of the Lexington. And Yorktown severely damaged.  59. The camera PANS to reveal a second carrier: the Yorktown. She's burning from a bomb strike amidships.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dammit. Why couldn't we have been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halsey paces on the bridge, a bundle of raw emotions. The flag officers are staying out of his way.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: This leaves us and Hornet as the only carriers in the Pacific.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. And Hornet is so green that she looks like a goddamned floating Christmas tree. (beat ) We're the one ship standing between the Japanese and the West Coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen pilots read and play cards. Halsey enters and the men instantly snap to attention.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: I want to see Best and McClusky. The other pilots quickly exit. It's clear from Best and McClusky's expressions that they are wondering why their admiral wants to see them alone.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At ease. Right. They nevertheless do their best to appear relaxed. alséy, meanwhile, leans against the wall and stares at th flight board, absentmindedly scratching his side. Best no the deep bags under Halsey's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Are you okay, admiral?

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: I'm not sleeping. Got some kind of strange rash... Halsey catches himself and squares his shoulders, the usu bulldog expression returning to his face.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm done playing politics. This ship is about to run a gauntlet, so I need my best men in the right spots. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to McClusky) You're now in charge of the whole air group. I don't have a lick of confidence in those damn torpedoes, so I want you in a dive bomber. (to Best) And I'm bumping you up from second in command of Bombing Six. You're the new skipper. The two men are speechless; all they can do is pull thems into a pair of crisp salutes. Halsey gives them a hard lo

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Navy -- hell, the whole damn country -- is counting on you. So don't screw it up. And then he stomps out of the room, leaving Best and McCl alone with their new responsibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yamamoto marches down a hallway. Men are SHOUTING behind closed door. He throws it open and bursts into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shouting instantly ceases as Yamamoto enters. A dozen officers stand around a giant table covered with a map. T ship models cover the central Pacific, and dice lie ona felt pad -- it's a massive war game.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Why are you arguing? This is no way to conduct a war game. ADMIRAL NAGUMO, 61, stands in the center of the room, his face red. A row of medals hang from his chest, and he fil out his uniform like a samurai... but appearances lie. He a dull and utterly unimaginative commander. Nagumo gestures at a JUNIOR OFFICER who is wearing an arm marked with an American flag.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: That young fool deviated from doctrine. Nagumo's finger juts at_the center of the giant map, wher four Japanese carriers lie to the west of Midway Island.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I followed your plan. We attacked Midway with the carriers... Nagumo's finger moves west to a thick cluster of ships.  61.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...while our battleships waited here to spring the trap. My carriers were ready to pivot as soon as the Americans responded from Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: But...? Everyone's attention turns to the junior officer. He swal hard, trying to find his confidence.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR OFFICER
dialogues.text: ny forces didn't come from Pearl. They were waiting to the northeast and launched their strike while Admiral Nagumo's planes were occupied bombing Midway. I sunk three of his carriers.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: Such a move is impossible. Unless the Americans know we are coming. Tamon speaks from the corner of the room, where he has be watching the debate like a hawk.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: But what will you do if you are wrong? If the Americans have the advantage of surprise? Nagumo gives Tamon an imperious look, displeased with the challenge from a subordinate. GENDA MINORU, 37, the cocky young officer responsible for air operations in the fleet responds on his behalf with a dismissive wave.

dialogues.speaker: GENDA
dialogues.text: One touch of the armored gauntlet. Yamamoto stares at Nagumo, his expression demanding a mor detailed explanation. Nagumo shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: Genda is right. Our defensive power is unbreakable. Yamamoto considers this for a moment and then turns to th young officer playing the Americans.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Start again. But this time your carriers must come from Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon stands near the sharp prow of the mighty warship, staring out at the vast fleet. It's a remarkable collecti of military might, yet Tamon's brow is furrowed. Yamamoto approaches. After a long moment --  62.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: You don't approve.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: I never liked Kabuki theater. And it worries me that Nagumo can't even win a war game without cheating.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: All he has to do is follow the plan. (beat ) And so do you. Tamon hears the subtext in those words: we might be frien but I am your superior officer. So he keeps his mouth shu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The squadron's pilots are sprawled across the chairs. Dickinson, who is writing a letter, notices Best enter.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Ten-hut! The pilots snap to their feet. Best rolls his eyes and th locks on Dickinson, who is fighting a smirk.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Funny. (to the men) Sit the hell down. As they settle back into their chairs --

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you heard the news. I know some of you thought I was a pain-in-the-ass as an XO, but it's about to get worse. (beat ) We're headed back to Pearl to resupply, and it's probably because something big is coming down the pipe. I'm therefore doubling scouting flights, and I expect you to practice diving runs whenever you get a chance. Don't be the guy who lets down the squadron when we finally face the Japs. Best surveys the room; the levity is gone.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dismissed. Best turns to the ready board and stares at it as the men silently file out the door behind him. Willie, however, s behind. When everyone else is gone, Best glances at him.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah?  63. The words come in a rush.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can do this, sir. I thought I was a good pilot, but I've totally lost my confidence. Best stares at Willie, weighing him. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Why did you join the Navy? Were you trying to impress some girl? Even Willie can't help being insulted by the question.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I wanted to be a pilot.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Then you've gotta suck it up. Look around, kid. America is getting its ass kicked, so nobody has time to worry about your confidence. We need you up in the air. Got it? The direct challenge to his manhood has stiffened Willie' spine. He speaks through tight lips.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. As Willie turns to exit, an instinct tells Best that he h pushed too hard. He calls after Willie --

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Wait. (Willie pauses) From now on you're my wingman. This news is simultaneously comforting and terrifying to Willie. He stands frozen, wondering whether this new posi means that Best might give him more advice. But Best has already turned back to the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz sits at his desk, shuffling through papers. Layton knocks on the doorframe and then enters.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with Washington. They think that you and Rochefort are wrong about this big operation. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Their intelligence indicates that the Japs are sending their carriers back into the Coral Sea, so they've ordered me to keep Enterprise down there.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Washington is starting from a faulty assumption and looking for evidence to corroborate it. If you listen to them, we'll all end up as POws. Layton regrets the final words as soon as they come out o his mouth; he's usually better at politics. But Nimitz ju leans back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: So what's the Japs' real target?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Midway Island. They see it as a step toward Hawaii. And the West Coast. Nimitz's eyes flicker to the map and then back to Layton.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: In the next few weeks. Nimitz studies Layton and sees nothing but absolute convi in his expression. He pushes himself to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Show me. If I'm going against Washington, I need to know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz's staff car pulls up in front of the drab Old Administration Building. Sailors and secretaries gawk as Nimitz emerges from the sedan and strides inside with Lay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Layton and Nimitz head down a linoleum-clad hall toward a staircase. As they start into the bowels of the building, Layton gives Nimitz a nervous look.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I have to warn you, sir. Rochefort's way of doing things is... particular.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I don't care if he's consulting an oracle if the intelligence is good.  65. They reach a door marked "Station HYPO." It's guarded by armed Marine, who opens the door for them. They enter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The open room is stuffed with metal desks and IBM punchca machines. A few dozen men in Navy khakis perform a variet of tasks, laughing and joking as they work until -- -- they notice Nimitz and snap to attention. Suddenly, th only sound is the mechanical rattle of the IBM machines. Nimitz glances down at the desk next to the door. A colle of pinups lies under the glass and a hand-printed sign re "You don't have to be crazy to work here... but it helps. As Nimitz smiles thinly to himself, Layton follows his ga to the pinup. He turns to the nearest man, mortified.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Where's Rochefort? The man points to the office in the back of the room. Nim starts in that direction, Layton trailing him.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: It's crowded in here.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: We've tripled the staff.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I didn't realize that the Navy had so many trained codebreakers.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: We don't. (off Nimitz's look) Most of these men were in the band on the California. Since we don't have much use for bands these days... Nimitz gives him a skeptical look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musicians?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Rochefort thought their musical ability might make them naturals at breaking the rhythms of ciphers. And he was right... the men in this room process a million punch cards per week. Layton opens a door and they step into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochefort is shaking a pill into his hand as they enter. quickly swallows it and then leaps to his feet, revealing  66. that he's wearing slippers and a smoking jacket. He nervo gestures at his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: Sorry, admiral. It gets cold down here in the dungeon. Nimitz ignores the apology. His icy eyes note the cot in corner before boring into Rochefort.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Layton tells me that you're confident the Japs are going to hit Midway.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Nimitz makes a gesture that encompasses the whole operati

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Explain how this works.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: We intercept roughly sixty percent of secure Japanese radio traffic. We've cracked enough of their code to be able to break about forty percent of those messages.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: So... we can read about a quarter of their secure communications.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: Not exactly. Here are some of our "cracked' messages. Rochefort pushes a bunch of papers toward Nimitz. He glan down and sees that only about ten percent of the words ar broken -- the rest are just numbers and letters.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: This is gibberish.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: Yes, but if you read enough of it...

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Rochefort has a gift for assembling the fragments. He can recall a detail from a message two months ago and plug it into today's intercept.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Do you have any direct proof that Midway is the target?

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: Direct proof? No.  67. Rochefort sees the doubt in Nimitz's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Imagine you're throwing a wedding. Maybe I've never seen the invitation, but I hear from the caterers that they have an event on a certain date. The flower guy is buying every rose on the island. The best band is booked. That's what signal intelligence can give you. Clues. Not the smoking gun. Nimitz takes a heavy breath -- obviously on the fence. La steps forward, passion propelling his words.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Sir, you should have fired me after Pearl Harbor. But instead you gave me a chance to redeem myself. (beat) I swear to you. Rochefort is right about this. Nimitz glances back and forth between the two officers. I crazy to be betting on this madhouse staffed by tuba play and run by a man in fuzzy slippers. And yet...

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I'll get Enterprise back to Pearl. But we need Washington on board, so you have to figure out a way to convince them that they're wrong about Midway. Layton hears the subtext in the speech: and if I'm going put my career on the line, you need to convince me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halsey works at his small desk, looking even more haggard than the last time we saw him. He turns his head at a KNO on the door. It's Browning, holding a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Sir, an eyes-only message from Nimitz. Halsey takes the paper. A hint of a smile runs across his face as he reads it.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: He wants us to get spotted.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: Because if we're spotted, we can break our standing orders from Washington and head back to Pearl.  68. Halsey picks up a lighter from the desk. As the slip of p in his hand ignites, he glances at Browning.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We never got this message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Layton paces as Rochefort lies on his cot, red eyes stari up at the ceiling. Rochefort finally rolls over and grabs pill bottle from the desk. As he swallows one --

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: What is that? Benzedrine?

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: I have to stay awake somehow.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Are you eating anything? Rochefort shrugs. Layton's face registers his concern.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At least take it with water. So you don't die of dehydration. Rochefort's eyes abruptly widen -- his face practically illuminated by the light bulb going off over his head.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: Wait. That's it! Layton stares curiously at Rochefort as he rustles throug the piles of paper on his desk. He pulls out a message wi the letters "AF" circled in red ink.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Washington agrees with us that the Japanese are going to attack a target codenamed AF. But they believe AF is in the South Pacific and nothing we say can change their minds.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Yeah...?

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: The problem is the messenger. Their ego won't let them admit that we're right and they're wrong. But what if we let the Japanese tell them? Off Layton's intrigued look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calling this little spit of sand in the center of the Pac Ocean an "island" is really glorifying it. Every square i of dry land is covered by a military airfield, swarms of anti-aircraft batteries, and barracks. A COLONEL strides toward a utilitarian building with gian radio signal masts on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the colonel enters, a LIEUTENANT snaps to attention.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Cable from Pearl, sir. They want us to broadcast that our fresh water facility has broken. And they want us to use the old strip cipher code.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: I thought that code was compromised when the Japs took Wake. The lieutenant shrugs -- this is above his pay grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty radiomen sit at their posts, listening to transmis through bulky headphone and carefully transcribing what t hear onto slips of paper. In an adjacent room, visible through a pane of glass, a l of officers attempt to decode the captured messages. One the men stands and waves over his superior. They talk M.O.S., their rising excitement palpable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz glances up from his desk as Layton enters.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I just heard from Washington. They intercepted several Japanese messages claiming that the target of their upcoming attack is out of fresh water.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: That's interesting, sir. I heard that Midway Island sent out a transmission that their water plant was broken.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Is their water plant broken?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Not that I know of, sir.  70. Nimitz can't contain a slight smile of appreciation at hi junior officers' cleverness. But it quickly fades.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Tell Rochefort that everyone now agrees where his wedding is going to be held. But I need to know how many guests are going to come. And when they're planning to arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four SBDs are spotted on the deck for takeoff. Best stick his head into the cockpit of the second plane in line. Wi stares back at him, face pale in the morning light.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Simple scouting mission. On the way home we'll practice a dive. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: We're going. steeper this time. Listen to your radioman count the altitude. And YGon' t pull up too hard at the bottom or you'll black out. Best drops back down onto the teak deck, jogs to the lead plane, and swings into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best revs the engine and the launching signal officer poi his flag toward the bow. Best releases his brake, and the SBD accelerates down the deck... .but just before the end of the runway Best realizes that something is wrong. He shoves the throttle forward, but t engine is already running flat-out.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. The SBD lurches off the end of the deck and falls toward ocean. Best expertly fights the stall and drops the nose, trading altitude for speed. Murray just closes his eyes, worst fears realized, and braces for impact... -but at the last instant -- when the wheels are mere feet from the waves -- Best gently pulls back on the stick. Th SBD reluctantly starts to rise. Best immediately shouts into the radio --

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Abort! Abort takeoff!  71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickinson emerges from the hatch in the island and sprint toward the launching signal officer. He's shouting someth but the engine roar from the remaining SBDs muffles the w AS Willie's plane accelerates, Dickinson snatches the fla and waves it back and forth in the abort signal.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: The ship's too slow. We're not generating enough wind for launch. The news horrifies the officer. Dickinson, meanwhile, kee waving the flag, but Willie's nervous eyes are fixated on the edge of the Enterprise ahead of him. As the plane reaches the end of the deck, it drops toward the ocean. Willie, unlike Best, keeps his nose up, and th plane flutters like a falling kite toward the waiting sea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best watches, horrified, as Willie's SBD knifes into the ocean. Enterprise turns, her prow barely missing the plan but the wake shoves one wing under the water. Best yanks on his stick to circle the wreck, his eyes loc on the rescue destroyer. It's still hundreds of yards awa

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: (into radio) He's going under, goddammit. Tell that rescue crew to move their ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wave breaks over the windshield as Willie frantically p at his straps, the cockpit already half-submerged. In his panic Willie inhales a mouthful of seawater. As he retches, another wave smashes over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halsey paces, brow knitted with worry, as Browning stares out the window through binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: The plane just went under.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: And the crew? Browning just grimly shakes his head. Halsey looks as if he's about to be sick.  72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best slams his fist against the side of his cockpit, face red with anger and frustration.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: No, goddammit. No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enterprise cuts through the early morning fog toward her berth. The giant American flag flies at half mast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air group stands in formation in their white uniforms the Marine guard presents arms. Five pilots -- including Best and McClusky -- are at the front of the group. Nimitz moves down the line, pinning medals to the men's chests. He pauses in front of Best.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: They tell me you were a one-man wrecking ball in the Marshall Islands. Best's eyes are hollow; he hasn't slept since Willie's cr He has to force the response.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: We all did our duty, sir. Nimitz leans close, his tone conspiratorial.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I think you'll have a chance to do it again in a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceremony has just ended. Halsey stands on the bridge, watching his pilots on the deck below him. As Nimitz ente Halsey shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: They're good kids. I've asked a lot of them, and they've done it without flinching. But it's been six months without a break. They're worn out. Nimitz takes stock of Halsey and is shocked by what he se the loss of weight, his pallid face, an angry red rash.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: They aren't the only ones. You look like hell, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: HALSEY
dialogues.text: I'm fine.  73. But even Halsey knows it isn't true. Nimitz shakes his he

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: You're going ashore to the hospital -- (Halsey starts to object) -- and that's a direct order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Best strides up the driveway, still wearing his dress whites, Ann emerges from the house. An enormous smile spl her face when she sees him.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I heard a ship's horn. I was praying it was Enterprise. Best pulls her into his arms, and they hold each other fo long moment. She finally pulls back to look at him. Her e lock on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that a medal? (he nods) Did you get it for doing something stupid?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Is there any other way to get a medal? She smiles. But then she notices his haunted look.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I just want to come inside. See our daughter. Sit for a while. Ann blinks; this isn't the man she knows. But she's wise enough to just take his hand and lead him into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a more subdued mood tonight -- no band and only a smattering of women. McClusky and Dickinson drink in the corner with Thatch and Gay (the pilots from Hornet). Thatch is in the middle of an intense explanation. He's u four quarters laid out on the table to illustrate a point

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: The problem is the Jap's fighters are faster and more maneuverable than us. But we can take more punishment. So I came up with this... Thatch moves the quarters on the table in a distinctive crossing pattern.  74.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We fly in tight formation, weaving back and forth across each other's tails. Whenever a Jap lines up to take a shot, your partner and his wingman get a clean look at him. McClusky gives the quarters a doubtful look.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: You've practiced this?

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: In San Diego. Worked like a charm.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Hope you're right. (shifting gears) So they moved you over to Yorktown. How are the other squadrons?

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: The fighter groups are great. Dive bombers are strong. The torpedo bombers, on the other hand... Everyone looks at Gay. He shrugs, unoffended.

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: It's not our fault the damn torpedoes don't explode.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Not to mention that your planes are slower than molasses.

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: Hey, you gotta admit it takes a pair to fly a deathtrap. The group smiles -- Gay might be a torpedo guy, but he cl has the right stuff. Dickinson pulls out his flask and po a heavy slug into Gay's glass.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Which is why I'm buying you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: I think you guys on Enterprise are the ones who need the drink. Yorktown is sitting this one out.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: The damage is that bad?

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: She got a bomb right down the elevator. They have to rebuild the whole guts of the ship.  75.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: We'll fly with you boys next time.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: If there is a next time. McClusky raises his glass. The others match him.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: To coming back. The words hang in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best lies with his head on Ann's lap, the curtains waving the warm Hawaiian breeze.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I got promoted. Halsey made me the new skipper of Bombing Six.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: You don't sound happy. I thought that's what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I thought it was what we wanted.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: It is. It's just... I didn't think that I'd worry this much. (beat) vesterday morning Betty Herman was getting her boys ready for school -- just like any other day -- until two officers in full dress showed up on her porch. And before they said a word, she knew her kids were going to grow up without a father.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: We keep losing men, and it's not even the Japs. Herman crashed on takeoff, Tom Durkin disappeared on patrol. So did Bucky Walters. And then there was this other kid. Willie west. Best swallows hard, eyes locked on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was so green. Told me that he didn't think he could cut it, but it seemed like the usual jitters. I figured I'd take him under my wing... (beat) I wrote a letter to his mother yesterday morning. Telling her that I failed him.  76. Ann stares down at her husband; she's never seen this kin of emotion from him before.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: It's not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I thought I was supposed to push him. That's what my XO did to me, and it made me a better pilot. But he wasn't ready.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Nobody's ready for war.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: The thing is... Willie was right to be scared. Everyone knows something big is coming. And I believe in my guys -- we can stand against anyone. But we're talking about a couple dozen planes against the whole Japanese fleet. And if we lose, they'll own the Pacific. Australia will fall, maybe Hawaii too. They'll raid the West Coast. San Francisco and Seattle and Los Angeles will burn. This damn war will last a decade. For a long moment Ann is frozen. The look on Best's face unsettles her even more than his words.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I've never seen you worried before.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I didn't have anything to worry about when it was just me and the plane. But it's different now. He looks up at her, emotionally naked.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think I can lead the squadron?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Of course you can. Just be honest. Let them see what I can see. beat) I'd follow you anywhere, Dick Best. She leans forward and kisses his forehead. Best closes hi eyes, his worries briefly abating in the warmth of her be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fleet is blacked out for security. Tamon stares out a the ghostly outlines of the nearby ships, lost in thought  77. A door opens behind him, briefly spilling the sound of a raucous party. Tamon remains motionless as Nagumo lurches over to him, drunk. Nagumo gives him a disdainful look.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: Your face depresses me. Tamon ignores him. Nagumo flushes.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are_ you too good to drink with your fellow officers?

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: It's bad luck to celebrate before a battle. Tamon turns on his heel and strides away, leaving Nagumo alone in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hungover crew of enlisted seamen hose vomit out of the ship's scuppers. They pause to glance through the mist at -- four enormous Japanese carriers heading out to sea, followed by a slew of escorts: battleships and cruisers a destroyers. It's an overwhelming display of force. A long figure stands on the bridge of the last carrier, Hiryu. It's Tamon. He has strapped his katana sword to hi sash like a Samurai headed into battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz crouches on the deck of the Yorktown, staring into the crater made by the bomb. Arc welders illuminate the s accompanied by the deafening sound of hammers pounding me The contrast between the vast Japanese fleet and this wou ship couldn't be more stark: How can the Americans possib win given their resources? An anxious Navy Yard INSPECTOR stands next to Nimitz.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: We need at least two weeks. Nimitz gives him a look that could freeze water. The insp shifts, defensive.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our initial estimate was three months in a dry dock at Puget.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I need this ship, so I don't care if you have to patch the deck with plywood. Yorktown sails in twenty- four hours.  78. We see nothing but doubt on the inspector's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant chart of the Pacific lies on a makeshift table he up by a pair of sawhorses. Tracing paper covers the chart with the estimated position of Japanese ships in orange a American ships in blue. Nimitz stands over the table with Layton and Rochefort an his core group of senior officers.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I have bad news. Admiral Halsey is in the hospital and will be unable to lead this operation. The room blanches. Nimitz turns to the officer standing n to him: REAR ADMIRAL RAYMOND SPRUANCE, 55. Spruance is sh and wiry and has earned a reputation within the Navy for being both a thinker and a doer.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have given Admiral Spruance the Enterprise. Our mission is simple. We must try to inflict maximum damage with attrition tactics. Nimitz taps Midway on the map.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have put every plane we could fit on Midway's runway, but those men aren't nearly as well trained as our carrier aviators. The responsibility for winning this battle therefore falls on you. Spruance stares down at the chart. Most men would be overwhelmed, but he's just absorbing the information.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: How reliable are these estimates of the Japanese positions?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: They represent our best guess based on the intelligence that we have. That answer doesn't satisfy Spruance at all.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: I can't plan around a guess. Nimitz locks on Layton.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: I understand that I'm asking the impossible, but I need you to be (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: specific. Everything depends on our forces being in the right place at the right time. Layton considers the question and then turns to Rochefort who is standing in the corner of the room. Everyone follo Layton's look. The attention briefly causes Rochefort to shrink into him but then he swallows hard and speaks in a level voice.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: The Japanese will attack on the morning of June fourth from the northwest at a bearing of 325 degrees. They will be sighted 185 miles from Midway at 0700 local time. A STAFF OFFICER speaks from the corner.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF OFFICER
dialogues.text: Washington disagrees.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Washington is wrong. Again. That last word lands. Everyone in this room remembers wha happened just six months earlier. Nimitz turns to Spruanc

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: These are the men I trust, so make your plans accordingly. Spruance nods. As he turns to exit, Nimitz stares down at the chart. He speaks to himself.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's all over but the shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halsey, wearing a patient's bathrobe and trailing an IV, stares out at Pearl Harbor. Enterprise has just slipped h berth and is heading back to sea. Halsey's eyes are filled with tears. He has prepared for moment his entire life and considers the men on that ship family -- yet at this critical moment he's stuck ashore. It breaks his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spruance stands by himself near the windows of the bridge staring up at a squadron of planes. Browning approaches h

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Are you ready to land Torpedo Six?  80.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Get ‘em aboard. Browning gestures to the signal officer. A moment later t lead plane in formation -- a torpedo bomber -- starts its approach. Spruance watches with a furrowed brow as the pl slowly closes on the Enterprise's wake.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm no pilot, but does he look slow? An instant later the TBD stalls. Its left wing dips and t the four-ton aircraft smacks into the water with a gigant splash. Browning just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Jesus. Another?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rescue destroyer comes alongside the wrecked TBD, whi is sinking at the nose. The radioman and GUNNER hold Lind on the wing. Blood runs down Lindsey's face from a bad cu As the destroyer's crew reaches down to pull him aboard -

dialogues.speaker: GUNNER
dialogues.text: Easy. He hurt his back. The crewmen gingerly lift Lindsey over the rail, but he nevertheless winces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best pours over a chart with the estimated Japanese posit marked in red. Dickinson enters and walks over to the tab He looks down at the chart, head shaking.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: We got the Jap positions and everything, huh? Our man in Tokyo is worth every cent we're paying him. A slight smile from Best. Dickinson studies the chart.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Four enemy carriers. Plus the biggest battleship in the world and countless cruisers and destroyers...

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: The odds aren't good. But if we surprise them, we've got a chance.

dialogues.speaker: . DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Even without Yorktown? The other guys think it's a suicide mission. Dickinson's tone suggests that he might share their opini Best turns and gives him a long look. Finally --  81.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: How do I get the men to believe?

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: In you or the mission?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Both.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: They just need to know that you believe in them. Even though“they aren't as good as you. And then they'll follow you into hell. As Best processes the words, a door slams open and an ENS bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ENSIGN
dialogues.text: Ship sighted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of men stand on the rail, staring at an approach boxy gray shape on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: It's Yorktown! A CHEER goes up from the men as they realize he's right. we're still underdogs, but at least we have a chance. Best and Dickinson, meanwhile, burst out of a hatch. Dick locks on Yorktown, head shaking.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: How the hell did she get out of drydock in time? Best shrugs. But his relief is written on his face.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Every good battle needs a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock reads almost midnight. A bleary Layton glances back and forth between cable intercepts and the giant cha Nimitz enters and gives Layton a look.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: You've memorized every position on that board, Layton. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I'm going to sleep here, sir. Just in case something comes up.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Your wife doesn't mind?  82.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: She knows the drill.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: My wife knows the drill too, but she still minds. Layton hears the subtext in Nimitz's words. He thinks for long moment and then decides to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: If Miriam doesn't divorce me, I'm going to spend the rest of my life making it up to her. Nimitz bobs his head: a faint gesture of recognition. As steps out of the room --

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best crouches under the wing of an SBD, meticulously inspecting every rivet and seam. A young WATCH OFFICER co around the corner, footsteps echoing in the deserted hang He gives Best a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: Are you okay, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Just looking over the planes. The watch officer can't help asking...

dialogues.speaker: WATCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: Is it true, sir? Are we finally facing the Japs tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I hope so. The watch officer nods to himself -- seemingly reassured Best's quiet confidence -- and then beats a retreat. Best, meanwhile, continues his lonely vigil. As he moves the next plane, the notes of reveille PLAY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American flag rises in the first rays of the sun asa lone Marine sounds his bugle. The final notes are drowned out by the rising HOWL of air raid sirens.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: A small camera crew is filming the scene, led by JOHN FOR 47. A MARINE CAPTAIN standing next to Ford gives him a lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you wanted to see action, Mr. Ford. I don't think you're going to be disappointed. The Marine points to the west, and Ford swings his camera dark cloud of Japanese aircraft are inbound. Anti-aircraf emplacements burst into action with a deafening roar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz paces, arms folded, as his officers do their best stay out of his way. An ENSIGN runs into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ENSIGN
dialogues.text: Japanese air attack reported on Midway. And one of our scout planes just sighted the enemy carriers. Nimitz locks on the ensign like a cobra.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Spotted where?

dialogues.speaker: ENSIGN
dialogues.text: He reports carriers bearing 320 degrees 180 miles northwest of Midway. Nimitz half-smiles to himself and then turns to Layton, w is marking the reported position on the giant chart.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Well, Layton... you and Rochefort were only off by five minutes, five degrees, and five miles.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: We'll endeavor to do better next time, sir. Another ghost of a smile from Nimitz. Then --

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Give Spruance the enemy position and tell him to attack.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Midway has already launched their B- 26s and a squadron of Marine dive- bombers. They should be approaching the Japanese carriers.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF OFFICER
dialogues.text: The Marines just got those planes a few days ago. Do they actually know how to fly them? Nimitz's blue eyes bore into the officer, who suddenly wi that he was a thousand miles away.  84.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: If I know the Marines, they'll do their damnedest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAJOR HENDERSON, 35, stares out the cockpit window. The e Japanese carrier task force stretches ahead of him. As Henderson flicks the toggle of his radio, we note the Mar Corp patch on his arm and the olive-drab color of his uni

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HENDERSON
dialogues.text: Beginning my run. Stay on me. Henderson gently pushes his flight stick forward, but jus as the aircraft begins to drop -- RAT-TAT-TAT! The sound of an automatic cannon rattles our eardrums. Henderson looks right just in time to see his m gas tank ignite in a blinding fireball.

dialogues.speaker: SKY
dialogues.text: We're watching the incoming American attack through a pai of binoculars. The fireball that used to be Henderson's p is surrounded by a dozen other SBDs, which are under vici assault by at least ten Japanese Zeroes. Another SBD abruptly dips its wing and falls toward the o trailing black smoke. And then another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon stands at the window in the cramped space, staring through mounted spotting binoculars. Henderson's entire squadron is coming straight for his ship. CAPTAIN KAKU TOMEO, 48, peers over Tamon's shoulder. Kaku a burly man with a narrow mustache over his scowling mout

dialogues.speaker: KAKU
dialogues.text: Why are they attacking at sucha shallow angle?

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: They're glide bombing. Which means they're amateurs. Tamon lowers his binoculars and looks at the helmsman.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Prepare for evasive action. Even amateurs can get lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five-inch guns atong the ship's port side swing into position in unison and belch shells into the sky. One of approaching planes loses control and drops like a stone, the others gamely continue their runs until...  85. ...black objects drop toward us. Bombs. The deck tilts as the carrier turns at high speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men on the deck gasp as Hiryu disappears behind a set enormous water spouts. Has she been hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men take cover as a wall of water hammers into the window of the bridge. The ship lurches. And then... Silence. Just the dim hum of the carrier's engines. As th other man gather themselves, they realize that Tamon is s standing watch at the window. He points to the south.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Look. We follow his finger and SMASH ZOOM toward a smoke trail the sky. It's a B-26 flaming from its left wing. The plan is in a shallow dive, headed straight for the central isl of the Akagi. Muzzles flash as Japanese gunners desperately unload with everything in their arsenal. The officers on the bridge s up at the bomber, mouths agape in astonishment, until -- WHOOSH! The plane's wing explodes and it veers hard to th right -- missing the bridge by mere yards -- before smash into the sea. But we stay with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nagumo stands with his stunned flag officers. Genda, the arrogant air commander, glances incredulously at his admi

dialogues.speaker: GENDA
dialogues.text: Was he trying to hit us?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: Americans aren't that brave. His controls must have locked up. Nagumo's words are dismissive, but his tone makes it clea that he is rattled. He thinks for a long moment. Then --

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Those planes came from Midway, which means it's still a threat. We must launch a second attack.

dialogues.speaker: GENDA
dialogues.text: But Admiral Yamamoto ordered us to keep our reserve force aboard in case we encounter enemy carriers. Nagumo flushes with anger.  86.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: Yamamoto is hundreds of miles away in his battleship. It's my decision. And that island must be neutralized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SBD pilots, dressed in their flight suits, eat breakf at a long table. The food is like sawdust in most of thei mouths, but not Best -- he's eating with gusto. As Best finishes his plate, he notices that Dickinson has barely touched his eggs.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Get something in your stomach. It's going to be a long day. Dickinson looks at him as if he's an alien, and Best abru registers the mood in the room. The man from the beginnin of our story would return to eating his food... ...but Best pulls a silver ring off his finger and tosses on the table. The other men stare at it, confused.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That belonged to Cliff Janz. When I decided to become a pilot, Cliff made me swap class rings. He said I'd be lucky to live to thirty, and he wanted to have something to remember me by. That's the kind of guy he was. Always busting your chops. beat) Cliff was aboard Arizona. His wife didn't even get a body to bury. The words hang in the air. Best pans the faces at the tab

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not going to sugarcoat it, boys. Nobody thinks we can go toe-to-toe with the Japanese, not in a fair fight. And today we're going to be big underdogs. Best stares around the table, his confidence and determin blazing from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me... I think the men in this room can fly with anyone. Maybe that's because I'm a cocky son-of-a-bitch. But it's also because I know all of you like brothers. I've seen what you can do. You're ready for this. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat ) Today we get square with the same bastards who bombed Pearl. Today we prove the American Navy isn't a joke. The pilots silently absorb his words. Dickinson finally n his own swelling confidence obvious in his expression.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: We're going to give 'em a shellacking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Enterprise is about five miles away as she swings int the wind, her escorts turning to match her new heading. A shape abruptly flashes past us and then disappears into cloud: it's a seaplane marked with the rising sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RADIOMAN listens intently to his headset and then leaps his feet. He salutes in the direction of Nagumo.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: Sir! A report from one of our aerial scouts. Ten enemy surface units spotted. Position east northeast. Nagumo furrows his brow.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL _NAGUMO
dialogues.text: Impossible. Why would enemy ships be east northeast?

dialogues.speaker: GENDA
dialogues.text: Unless it's a trap. The words hang in the air -- everyone in this room rememb the debacle during the war games. But Nagumo quickly rega his blustery confidence.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL _NAGUMO
dialogues.text: We will rearm our planes and then smash this new threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon stares through binoculars at a flashing signal ligh from Akagi. He shakes his head, face contorted in frustra

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: We should launch our reserve force now. But the old fool wants to wait. Everyone on the bridge avoids Tamon's dark gaze -- except Kaku, who tries to play the peacemaker.  88.

dialogues.speaker: KAKU
dialogues.text: He's following doctrine. It's always better to launch a balanced attack.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: I know the doctrine. But an admiral is supposed to lead, not follow. A WARNING BUZZER sounds through the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: Sir! Periscope spotted. Tamon raises his binoculars. He locks on a cruiser and tw destroyers a few miles away, which have turned hard and a accelerating toward a fixed point in the ocean. Several columns of spray spout into the air, followed by dull boom of depth charges. Tamon shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: An American submarine right in the middle of our fleet. Like a cat in the henhouse. Tamon watches the giant waterspouts from the depth charge and then turns to the signalman.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Order a destroyer to stay and pin it down. They can catch up once the rest of the fleet is safely out of range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SBD pilots stride to their planes, Best locks ona pair of ENSIGNS half-carrying a pilot toward one of the t ombers. Best looks closer, revealing that the pilot is. Lindsey. His face is drawn with pain, and he's wincing wi every Step. Best glances at the waiting torpedo bomber -- realizing that Lindsey is literally being carried to his plane -- and then veers into his path.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: You don't have to fly today. Nobody will doubt your courage. Lindsey shakes his head, jaw clenched with determination.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: This is what we trained for. I'll lead my squadron in. Best blinks, abruptly realizing how badly he has misjudge his counterpart. And he's a big enough man to say.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Good luck, Lindsey.  89.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: Thanks. We're going to need it. Best draws himself up and gives Lindsey a salute. Lindsey nods back at him in a silent exchange of respect.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll meet you at the Japanese fleet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Best revs his engine to prepare for takeoff, the radio of the plane in front of him catches his eye: Bruno Gaido He raises his arms, hands clasped in a victory Saluté, as his SBD accelerates down the deck. Best smiles and then flips his intercom.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Well, Murray. This is it. And then Best guns the throttle. As soon as the SBD is airborne, he fastens his oxygen mask and spins the dial o the oxygen cylinder -- -- but as the mix begins to flow he violently coughs and rips the mask away from his face. Murray hears the noise.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Are you okay, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Dammit all to hell... it's my oxygen cylinder. I've got a bad mix. As Murray processes the words, he tries -- and fails -- t contain his relief.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: We have to go back to Enterprise. Best's brow furrows as he considers his options. Murray longingly stares back at the carrier behind them -- a rel bastion of safety -- and tries to press the point home.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can't breathe a bad mix, sir. It will tear up your lungs.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I'm not sending the squadron out there without their commander. And then Best reaches up and fastens the mask back across his face. As the oxygen flows, his body is wracked by cou But Best ignores the burning in his pungs and grips the s There's no fucking way he's turning back.  90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIEUTENANT TOMONAGA, 32, climbs out of his B5N bomber. He notices Tamon striding toward the plane and snaps to atte

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: We've spotted enemy ships. Re-arm with torpedoes as quickly as possible. A SHOUT from a lookout interrupts the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE LOOKOUT
dialogues.text: Incoming! Tamon's head snaps around and he follows the lookout's outstretched finger to a glint of metal high in the sky. squadron of B-17s are droning toward them.

dialogues.speaker: LT. TOMONAGA
dialogues.text: Land based bombers. Maybe from Hawaii. Tamon watches with professional detachment as the bombers open their bay doors. Shapes plummet toward the carrier.. ...but from that altitude the bombs are in the air for al thirty seconds. The carrier swings into a tight turn and bombs explode harmlessly in the sea a few hundred yards a from the deck. Tomonaga shrugs, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: LT. TOMONAGA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They'll never hit us from that altitude. Tamon speaks over his shoulder as he starts back toward t carrier's island. His frustration is apparent.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Maybe not. But these constant attacks -- inept as they might be -- are keeping us on the defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best flies with one hand on the stick and the other holdi a pair of binoculars to his eyes. As he sweeps back and f across the desolate ocean --

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Either we got a bum sighting report or the Japs changed course. This isn't bad news to Murray. Best, meanwhile, glances o the window at the rest of the squadron. We follow his gaz and ZOOM to another SBD about a mile away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McClusky swings his own binoculars over the ocean, as frustrated as Best. But then he locks on a spot to the no  91.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: We got something. The binoculars reveal the wake of a ship heading north at flank speed -- the destroyer that _was panning down the American submarine. McCIusky's Speaks in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Looks like a Jap destroyer. What do you want to bet she's trying to catch up with the carriers? McClusky turns the stick and the SBD banks to match the c of the Japanese destroyer.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN, (V.O.)
