dialogues.text: How long can we follow her course before we run out of fuel?

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Not long. This decision weighs heavily on McClusky -- he knows that he's betting an awful lot on a hunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindsey flies just a few hundred feet above the ocean, th rest of his squadron trailing off his wing tips. A smudge smoke appears on the horizon, and Lindsey stares at it fo long moment before keying his radio.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: There they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatch's six-fighter squadron flies at eight thousand fee From this altitude he can see both Lindsey's torpedo squa and the Japanese ships on the horizon. His radio crackles

dialogues.speaker: FIGHTER PILOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Any word from the dive bombers?

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Negative . I think they flew a different heading.

dialogues.speaker: FIGHTER PILOT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? Those torpedo bombers are sitting ducks.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Which is why we're going to attract as much attention as possible.  92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gay stares fixedly at the smoke, which we can now see is coming from the stacks of various warships. Lindsey's voi echoes through his headset.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: Hammer attack on the closest carrier. Follow my lead. Gay banks to the right as his squadron splits into two pi His RADIOMAN speaks through the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You think they've seen us?

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: When they see us, we'll know it. Gay pushes his throttle wide open and the drone of the en rises in intensity. He glances down at the airspeed indic which is barely over a hundred MPH.

dialogues.speaker: GAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, you bitch. BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! The windscreen and instrument panel exp in a shower of glass. Gay catches just a glimpse of the speeding Zero -- it came out of the sun -- and then his p shudders under another barrage. Gay instinctively tries to bank the plane, but the stick dead in his hand. He jiggles it, helpless. Then --

dialogues.speaker: GAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Brace for impact! Gay manages to cover his head just as the plane slams int the water like a cement wall. He's hurled against the dashboard and then slumps back in his seat, dazed. Before can gather himself -- PING! PING! Bullets rattle against the exterior of the SB followed by the roar of a_Mitsibushi engine -- the Zeroes are strafing the downed plane. The sound galvanizes Gay. He tears off his strap and then turns to the back of the bomber.

dialogues.speaker: GAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! We gotta -- The words catch in Gay's throat as he realizes that his radioman and tail gunner have been shredded by gunfire. F an instant he is frozen by the horrific sight, but the ro of an engine forecasts another attack. Gay grabs the edge of the cockpit and swings himself over into the ocean --  93. -- and suddenly it's silent. The bright white streaks of bullets penetrate the turquoise sea like harpoons as Gay swims under the body of the aircraft for shelter. He holds his breath eyes bulging and hands clutching the aluminum. What the hell is he going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High above Gay's downed plane the six Wildcats of Thatch' squadron dogfight with at least twenty Zeroes -- the Japa pilots actually have to line up to take shots at them. One of the Wildcats is hit and drops toward the ocean, trailing black smoke from its engine.

dialogues.speaker: FIGHTER PILOT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Jesus. They're everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatch fights off the G-forces as he pulls his fighter in a tight turn. A Zero passes through his sights and he sna off a quick shot before yelling into his radio.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Form on me, boys. We're going to try that weave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flak bursts off the right wingtip. Lindsey ignores it, hi eyes locked on a Japanese carrier just two thousand yards front of his plane. The ship is speeding away from him, w water boiling from its stern.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sir! Can we drop? It's not a question; it's a plea. But Lindsey is intent o finishing his attack, and so he stays focused on the carr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four remaining Wildcats have formed into pairs and ar crossing back and forth across each other's tails as the dozens of Zeroes swarm around them. A Zero comes in for a pass on one of the Wildcat's tails, but just before it can get off a clean shot -- -- a trailing Wildcat swings into position and opens fire The lightly-armored Zero explodes into flame and drops li a rock toward the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatch works the stick, his head on a swivel. A victory Y comes through his radio.  94.

dialogues.speaker: FIGHTER PILOT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Scratch another Zero.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Attaboy. Only twenty more to go. The comment is punctuated by a Zero swinging into Thatch' sights. He takes the shot and watches with satisfaction a pieces fly off the right wing of the Japanese plane. But then he pans the sky.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can't hold them forever. Where the hell are those dive bombers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hiryu has grown in the windscreen and is now less tha thousand yards away. Lindsey stares through his sight lik man possessed, one hand clutching the torpedo release.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: This is for Pearl Harbor. And then he yanks the lever. The plane lurches upward as heavy torpedo barrels into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: Now can we get out of here, sir? BOOM! A cannon shell explodes in the right fuel tank. Lin turns his head just in time for his face to be illuminate by the ferocious explosion. The expression on his face is a mixture of resignation an acceptance. He did his duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon watches as Lindsey's TBD is ripped apart by the explosion. As the fragments fall into the sea --

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Brave men. We are fortunate they have such bad planes. Tamon turns his attention to a white streak bubbling towa the stern of the carrier.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right full rudder. The helmsman obeys his command and Hiryu pivots, the torp passing harmlessly through the wake. Tamon, meanwhile, raises his binoculars. A pack of Zeroes circles low off the ocean, searching in vain for more tor bombers to attack. A second pack is still taking a run at Thatch and his wingmen. Tamon grunts, frustrated.  95.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our fighters need to stop glory hunting. They're all too low. (beat ) This last attack was also carrier-based aircraft. Which means we are facing the exact situation that Nagumo declared impossible during our war games. This revelation sends a chill through the room. Tamon tur to the signal officer.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The time for diplomacy is over. Signal the flagship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SIGNAL OFFICER stares through binoculars at a flashing light on the bridge of Hiryu and then turns to Nagumo.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: A message from Admiral Yamaguchi, sir. 'Consider it advisable to launch attack force immediately.' As the words register with Nagumo, he flushes with anger.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: What does he think I'm trying to do? (to Genda) What's our status?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mechanics furiously repair and refuel planes as munitions teams rush from the magazine elevator with armor-piercing bombs and torpedoes. Gas lines weave back and forth acros the deck among discarded high-explosive bombs. This hanger is one tiny spark away from catastrophe. The DECK OFFICER holds a phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: DECK OFFICER
dialogues.text: We're going as fast as we can, sir. But it takes time to change from land weapons to sea weapons.

dialogues.speaker: GENDA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You have five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genda turns to Nagumo and gives him a smart salute.

dialogues.speaker: GENDA
dialogues.text: They're almost finished.  96.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: Good. We will launch a full attack and crush the enemy task force. A piercing WHISTLE abruptly seizes the attention of every on the bridge. A SPOTTER high on a mast outside the islan is pointing at the sky. The word carries clearly...

dialogues.speaker: SPOTTER
dialogues.text: Helldivers!!! Nagumo rushes to the window and cranes his head upwards. swarm of black dots are hovering above the carrier direct behind them in the formation (Kaga). Nagumo stares up at them, stunned. Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Japanese fleet lies below the Enterprise's thirty-one SBDs without a single enemy fighter to oppose them. Best gauges the four carriers (they're in a box formation) and then keys his radio.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: All right, boys. It's payback time. Yorktown's squadron will take the far two carriers, so we're on the near ones. Scouting Six, we've got the first bastard in line. Best yanks on his diving flaps, and the plane immediately slows. But then -- -- a SBD flashes ahead of him. The lead squadron has also started to dive. Best yanks on the stick and manages to a a mid-air collision by mere feet. As they flatten back ou Murray shouts from the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What the hell? McClusky was supposed to hit the far carrier! Best ignores him and glances out the window -- his two wi are still attached. He keys his radio again.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Stay on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane drops at terminal velocity toward the carrier. McClusky peers through his bombing sight, working the con to keep the "x" centered on the red dot squarely amidship His RADIOMAN shouts from the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: Twenty two hundred... two thousand...  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gay clutches a piece of wreckage as he bobs in the water squarely in the center of the Japanese fleet. His eyes ar locked on a thin line of black dots descending toward the Kaga. He whispers the words like a prayer.

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: Come on, baby. Come on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carrier's deck is rushing toward us as McClusky fight to keep the sight centered. The radioman shouts a warning

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: Eighteen hundred! McClusky yanks the release and then immediately pulls the stick. His body stiffens as the G-forces hit him, but he manages to peek over his shoulder... .just in time to see his bomb hit the water ten yards fro kaga' s bridge. McClusky curses -- he missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickinson is late in the line of planes. Just as he start his dive, he sees McClusky's waterspout. He locks on his bomb sight, speaking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Come on, Dickinson. Do what you're paid to do. Dickinson is halfway down to the carrier when he sees the deck ripple -- someone has planted his bomb squarely on t target. But Dickinson keeps his focus until...

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: Eighteen hundred! The plane lurches as Dickinson releases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gay watches, a quick cavalcade of bombs slam into kaga Her deck erupts in a series of explosions, and Gay punche the water, celebrating as if he's at a football game.

dialogues.speaker: GAY
dialogues.text: Yeah! Hell yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officers stare at Kaga, stunned. A collective groan g up from the group -- no ship could survive that barrage. panicked JUNIOR OFFICER abruptly points out the opposing window, his tone bordering on the hysterical.  98.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR OFFICER
dialogues.text: Look! Akagi is also under attack! Tamon gives the man a sharp glance.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Calm yourself. You're an officer. But Tamon can't contain his own wince as he sees the firs pair of bombs hit Akagi. Steam immediately rises from the aft elevator as the ship's turbines are breached. She's d in the water -- and another dozen planes are descending. Tamon grunts to himself and then hurries out onto --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scans the sky above his ship, but sees no planes. Kaku appears next to him, eyes panning back and forth between two stricken carriers.

dialogues.speaker: KAKU
dialogues.text: That leaves just us and Akagi. Tamon points at the sky above Akagi -- three lonely dots approaching at fifteen thousand feet.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Unless they hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best bores through the sky, eyes locked on the Akagi far below. She's at flank speed in a maximum starboard turn. The radio crackles in his ear -- it's his WINGMAN.

dialogues.speaker: WINGMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Feeling a little lonely, sir. Wish we'd brought more planes to the party.

dialogues.speaker: EST
dialogues.text: You always wanted to be a hero, Kroeger. This is your chance. Best hits the diving flaps. As the SBD rolls onto its bac Best speaks into the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, Murray. We put that carrier out of action even if we have to crash on her deck. We catch a brief glimpse of Murray's terrified face as th plane begins to plummet toward the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookouts scream as the gun barrels swing upward toward th sky above the ship.  99. Three lonely planes are diving at an impossibly-steep ang in a V formation. The guns fire in a ferocious fusillade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane vibrates as flak explodes on either side. But B ignores it, icy eyes locked on his bombsight.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two thousand... eighteen hundred! We expect Best to yank the lever. But he's motionless, ha making tiny adjustments on the stick.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sixteen hundred! There's no mistaking the tone of Murray's voice: sir, dro the goddamned bomb and let's get the hell out of here! Bu Best ignores him, totally focused on his target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nagumo stares up at the trio of planes. The first two hav pulled up, their ordinance released. One bomb splashes to the left of the bridge, sending up a sheet of water. The second misses a dozen feet off the stern. But the middle plane just continues to dive. It's so clos that Nagumo can hear the drone of its engine and see the red, white and blue insignia on the wings. Is this maniac going to crash into his fucking ship? And then the pitch of the engine changes and the plane pu out of its dive with a reluctant howl. An instant later N sees the bomb. It looks as if it's coming straight at him Nagumo instinctively ducks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the bomb detonates at the aft edge of the middle elevator. A blinding FLASH illuminates the bridge, follow by a percussion wave that hurls men to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane finally pulls level just a few dozen feet above the ocean. Murray strains against the G-forces to hold th rear-mounted .30 cals in place. His eyes widen as he sees planes being blown off the deck the bomb, and then he unleashes a rebel yell.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Ye-haw! That was a beaut, sir. Right on her deck. BOOM! A giant waterspout rises next to the plane -- ten stories high and nearly solid.  100. One of the nearby Japanese cruisers is firing into the oc Best wrestles the stick, zigging the plane back and forth Flak bursts around them along with another enormous pair waterspouts. Best abruptly pulls back -- -- and they soar over a Japanese destroyer, close enough that they can see the surprised faces of the AA gunners. The plane drops back down toward the waves, and suddenly it's eerily quiet. Best scans the horizon ahead of them a sees nothing but open ocean.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Any fighters on our tail? Murray nervously scans the sky and then exhales with reli

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: No, sir. They must be chasing other people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruno Gaido swings his .30 cal back and forth, hammering bullets at a Zero on his tail. The enemy fighter drops ou of range and Bruno pans the sky for another target. LT. O'FLAHERTY (his pilot) speaks in his headset.

dialogues.speaker: LT. O'FLAHERTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We're running out of fuel. Bruno glances out at the left wing and sees a stream of l illuminated by the midday sun.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: We've been hit. Left wing. And that's when the engine conks out. As Bruno registers unsettling silence, aherty shouts from the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: LT. O'FLAHERTY
dialogues.text: We're going in! Bruno braces himself as the plane's nose pitches down and the ocean comes rushing toward them. At the last moment O'Flaherty pulls up and the belly hits the ocean in a tex water landing, but Bruno slams his head against the guns. Bruno nevertheless jumps out onto the wing, bleeding from cut above his eye. A moment later O'Flaherty joins him clutching a bag that contains an inflatable raft. In the distance two Zeroes are chasing another SBD. Bruno gives the raft a dry glance.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Guess we're going to have to float back to Pearl.  101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're speeding just twenty feet above the water. McClus weaves back and forth between a pair of Zeroes, trying to keep them from getting a clean shot. The radioman glances at Bruno's floating SBD in the dista

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: O'Flaherty and Bruno are down.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: If you don't hit one of those damn Zeroes, we're going to join them. A Zero begins its firing run, and McClusky turns to port, his wingtip just feet above the waves. Bullets riddle the the SBD and McClusky grunts in pain -- a round has slamme into his shoulder. The radioman, meanwhile, gets a bead on the Zero and hamm bullets into its exposed belly as it flashes past them. T Japanese pilot loses control and slams into the sea. The radioman immediately wheels with the .30 cals, but th other Zero has had enough and peels away. The radioman bl surprised to be alive -- and then clicks the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: RADIOMAN
dialogues.text: You okay, sir? McClusky ignores the question, teeth gritted in pain. He glances down at his wrecked instrument panel.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Pray we've got enough fuel to get home to Enterprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A_ Japanese pilot stares down at his gas gauge, which is flickering near empty, and then glances below him at the stricken Kaga. His landing strip is burning from end-to-e As the plane passes through a column of smoke, we TILT an then DROP toward the carrier's deck. Giant wood planks ar scattered like Lincoln Logs. We continue to PUSH downward through the largest hole into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a scene from Dante's Inferno. Swirls of heavy s reveal twisted metal and mangled human remains. The injur lie moaning with nobody to help them as the able-bodied p buckets of water in a grim chain. A LIEUTENANT descends into the hellscape on a rope. As so as his feet hit the deck, the overwhelmed DAMAGE CONTROL OFFICER rushes to his side.  102.

dialogues.speaker: DAMAGE CONTROL OFFICER
dialogues.text: What are the captain's orders?

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: A bomb hit the bridge. They're all dead. It's up to us to save the ship. As the men continue talking, we follow the chain of bucke toward the forward elevator. Bombs and torpedoes lie amon the wreckage -- thousands of pounds of TNT -- and aviatio fuel drips from ruptured lines.

dialogues.speaker: DAMAGE CONTROL OFFICER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The gasoline is vaporizing.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE LIEUTENANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Activate the CQ2.

dialogues.speaker: DAMAGE CONTROL OFFICER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We have no power. The man at the end of the chain hurls his bucket of filth looking liquid down the elevator shaft. As it lands with hiss amid red-hot metal, we FOCUS on a stream of gasoline running down the far side of the shaft. The bottom droplet bubbles and then vaporizes with a hiss An instant later there's a brilliant flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men stare in horror as a massive fuel-air explosion nearl splits Kaga in half. An orange mushroom cloud rises from amidships, followed in quick succession by a series of sm blasts as the loose torpedoes and bombs detonate. We PAN to reveal that the men aboard Akagi have their own problems; flames are rippling up from the center elevator The fire has ignited a Zero, which burns like a torch. The heavy smoke washes over Nagumo. He stands next to the ship's compass, stunned into a state of utter shock. Gend screws up his courage and approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: GENDA
dialogues.text: Sir, we must go. Nagumo turns his dazed eyes to Genda.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL NAGUMO
dialogues.text: I have to save the ship.

dialogues.speaker: GENDA
dialogues.text: It's the captain's job to save the ship. Your duty is to lead. And you can't do that from here.  103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Japanese senior officers are lowered one-by-one from burning ship into a waiting launch. Nagumo's feet dangle awkwardly in the air as he clutches the rope. He looks utterly beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz paces back and forth, his legendary calm under ass from the stress of waiting for news. Layton approaches hi and speaks under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Do you want us to contact Admiral Spruance?

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: He can't break radio silence. And I'm sure he has plenty on his mind. (beat ) But this is torture. The words hang in the air until the door bursts open and Rochefort runs inside. He waves a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: We just intercepted a Japanese signal. We can't translate the body. But look at the call sign. Rochefort slaps the paper on the table, his finger pointi at a short string of letters and numbers.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's from Admiral Nagumo. But he's not transmitting from the Kaga. He's transmitting from a cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Why would Nagumo leave his flagship unless... A glint appears in Nimitz's eye.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: ...the Kaga is sinking. A charge runs through the men in the room as they absorb words. Could it be true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battleship Yamato cuts through dense fog, impossibly powerful and imposing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yamamoto pores over a map, brow furrowed. An AIDE strides into the room, face grim, and hands him a message.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: From Admiral Nagumo. Yamamoto snatches the message and quickly scans the characters. The corner of his mouth twitches. But his fac is otherwise stone. The other officers are desperate to know what the message contains, but nobody dares speak. Yamamoto turns and star out the window at the impenetrable fog. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: The Americans knew we were coming. We walked into their trap. The officers exchange an incredulous look: can that possi be true? Yamamoto takes a slow breath.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can still win. But we must know what we're facing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruno and O'Flaherty bob in their small raft. Bruno shiel his eyes against the sun as he stares at an approaching s

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: It's a destroyer.

dialogues.speaker: LT. O'FLAHERTY
dialogues.text: American or Jap? Bruno takes a hard look. He doesn't like what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: It's the Japs. And I don't think they're gunna be in a very good mood after what we did to their ships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruno and O'Flaherty stand against the rear rail, surroun by Japanese sailors. Their hands are bound and five-gallo drums of gasoline are lashed to their feet. A young Japanese LIEUTENANT speaks in broken English.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Where you come from?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Shangri-La.  105. Bruno says it with a straight face. The lieutenant turns his captain, and they have a short and intense exchange i Japanese. The lieutenant turns back to the Americans.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: You tell us your ships. Or we throw you overboard. O'Flaherty blanches. Bruno stares back at the lieutenant then flicks his head at one of the sailors who is smoking

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Cigarette. The lieutenant turns to the sailor and speaks in Japanese An instant later the lit cigarette is stuck between Bruno lips. He takes a deep drag, eyes locked on the captain.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I had a lot of friends at Pearl Harbor. Bruno exhales, smoke blowing in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So how about you go fuck yourself. The captain doesn't wait for the translation -- he hears everything he needs to know in Bruno's tone. He snaps his fingers at his men. Bruno doesn't try to struggle. He just stares down the ca as they lift him over the rail and dump him into the Paci a portrait in courage to the end. When he's gone, the lieutenant turns to O'Flaherty.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: You. Tell us your ships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon stands in the center of a circle of grim-faced pilo Their planes are spotted for launch on the deck behind hi

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: We are facing three American carriers. You are the last intact aircraft unit in the fleet, so the fate of Japan rests on your skill. The Emperor expects you to do your duty. The men nod -- the moment is too serious for cheering -- then start for their planes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiryu steams into the wind, Val bombers launching from he deck. The three other Japanese carriers blaze in the background as a reminder of the stakes.  106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Thatch swings out of his Wildcat onto the deck, the FL DECK OFFICER gives him a salute.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT DECK OFFICER
dialogues.text: Welcome back to the Yorktown, sir. The officer's eyes widen as he gets a closer look at the bullet holes in Thatch's plane.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT DECK OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jeez... did you take on the whole Jap Navy by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Sure felt like it. The dull THUD of distant explosions turns their heads -- carrier's escorts are firing flak at a pack of swiftly- approaching dark dots in the sky. Incoming aircraft.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Swing me around. The deck officer gives him a confused look.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT DECK OFFICER
dialogues.text: But, sir... you must be almost out of fuel. Thatch gives the officer a dry look.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: I'm not going to need much fuel. And then he jumps back into his cockpit. The officer WHIS and men rush to turn the plane back toward the bow. A mom later the Wildcat is roaring down the deck. As it leaps i the air, Thatch sees a burst of flak to his right. He banks towards it -- fighting every instinct for self- preservation -- and spots a Japanese torpedo bomber flyin just a hundred feet above the waves. Thatch flies straight at the bomber, closing the gap at o four hundred miles an hour. At the last instant he fires, and the planes pass within barely a dozen feet of each ot The Japanese crew stares back at him -- -- and then Thatch's cockpit is illuminated by an explosi as the bomber's fuel tank ruptures. Thatch doesn't take e a moment to celebrate; he just banks his plane looking fo another target. It's only been ten seconds since he left the Yorktown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatch locks on a dark shape flying close to the water -- another torpedo bomber. He pushes into a dive, jamming hi throttle fully open...  107. ...but when he depresses his trigger, nothing happens. Hi plane is out of ammo.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goddammit ! Thatch can only watch in frustration as the bomber drops torpedo just eight hundred yards away from the Yorktown. deadly fish leaves no wake as it runs toward its target.. THUD! The torpedo strikes the Yorktown directly amidships great geyser of water erupting from her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spruance stares through binoculars at a distant smudge of smoke and then grimly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: Yorktown's hit. That leaves just us and Hornet.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: Most of Hornet's air group managed to get lost and landed at Midway. Which means it's just us.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: What have we got left?

dialogues.speaker: FLAG OFFICER
dialogues.text: A couple of SBDs just landed. The pilots are coming up to report. Spruance waits, binoculars once again focused on smoke fr the burning Yorktown. Feet clang on the metal stairwell outside the bridge and then -- -- Best and McClusky enter. Spruance locks on them.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: What news from the enemy fleet?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Three carriers down. One to go.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: And our air group? Best and McClusky share a glance. This isn't good news.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Only three torpedo bombers came back, and they're all shot up.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: What about the dive bombers?

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: We can probably scrounge up a dozen.  108. Spruance isn't an easy man to rattle, but he's stunned by the stark reality of those numbers. He stares at Best and McClusky. That's when he notices...

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: Good God, McClusky. You've been shot. Everyone on the bridge turns to look. McClusky's uniform damp from his shoulder to his cuff, and the skin on the b of his hand is tinted red with blood. McClusky shrugs, embarrassed by the attention.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: I can fly.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: The hell you can. Get your ass down to the sick bay. Now. McClusky reluctantly exits the room. Spruance turns his attention to Best.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put the pilots you trust in any plane that can fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. As Best turns to exit --

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: Good luck, son. Best nods and is gone. Spruance stares after him, wonderi whether he's just condemned his remaining pilots to death

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best marches down a long corridor, but then stops and lea against a bulkhead, his body contorting in a brutal serie of wracking coughs. A passing SAILOR gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: You okay, sir? Best waves him off and catches his breath before entering

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-dozen exhausted pilots sit in silence, staring at status board. Two thirds of the planes have been labeled either shot down or missing in action. Best glances at a PILOT, who is updating the chart.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Dickinson didn't come back?  109.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. Best knows exactly what that means. He takes a slow breat trying to gather himself. And then --

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I know you boys have just come through hell. But we've gotta go back and hit that last carrier. There's a long moment of silence -- every man knows it's miracle that he returned alive from the first mission... ...but then they just stand and file out the door without single word of protest. Marching, perhaps, to their doom. Best watches them go, as proud as he has ever been in his life. The pilot who spoke glances back at him.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: I'll see if I can find more men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray sits on his bunk in the deserted room, hollow eyes staring at the wall. Best sticks his head inside.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Strap up. We're going back out.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. But I think you need to find someone else.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: What? The words pour out of Murray in a nervous torrent.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: You don't know what it's like to be in the back seat, sir. There's nothing I can do but pray. And you fly like you don't care if we come home. Best steps into the room, stunned. All he can ask is...

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Why didn't you transfer off my plane?

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Because the other guys would have given me hell. They would have asked why I was too scared to fly with the great Dick Best. As Best stares at Murray -- registering his pain and anxi he remembers his exchanges with Willie West.  110. Best needs Murray in his plane, but he also has grown eno understand this isn't a moment for a rah-rah speech; it's moment for honesty.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I want to go home too. Murray glances up at Best, caught off-guard.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to spend more than a few days at a time with my wife. I want to go fishing with my dad back in Jersey. I want to see my little girl get married. And yourre right... if we go back out there, we probably aren't going to come back. (beat ) But this is our job. We're the guys who have to hold the fort until the cavalry arrives. Best crouches. He's staring into Murray's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you really can't fly, I'll find someone cise. But you should get ack in that plane. For yourself. You'll remember this momen or the rest of your life. And if you know that you came through when people were counting on you... well, you'll be a different man. You'll be able to face anything. Best pauses. Murray can see that he's speaking from the h and he's hanging on every word.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've come this far, Murray. Don't make me go back out there without you. Murray thinks for a long moment, his fear wrestling his loyalty. And then he pushes himself to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: I'll start the inspection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Best emerges onto the deck, he notices Thatch standing amid a cluster of pilots. Best walks over to the group an sticks out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard. What are you doing over here? As Best and Thatch shake --  141.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: With Yorktown burning I didn't have anywhere else to land. (beat) I heard you're going back out there. Want some company?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: The more the merrier. Thatch flicks his head at the other pilots.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Some of my friends from Yorktown also wouldn't mind getting square. Best pans the men and then nods, a glint in his eye. His posse has just doubled in size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yamamoto studies the map. He finally looks up at his offi his air of command has returned.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: We will snatch victory from defeat. Yamamoto's finger juts toward the estimated position of t American fleet, which is marked with a grease pencil.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The enemy has lost a carrier and their air wings are weakened. We will draw them within range of our battleships and destroy them. Hiryu will provide air cover. The staff officers study the map.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF OFFICER
dialogues.text: It's a bold plan. The other men nod. Yamamoto turns to the signal officer.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: Radio Admiral Yamaguchi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone on the bridge watches intently as Tamon reads th message. He finally looks up.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Yamamoto is ordering us to charge. Like samurai trying to save our honor. It's clear from Tamon's face that he thinks the plan is foolish, but an order is an order -- especially from Yama He crumples the message.  112.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So it shall be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The golden late-afternoon sun reflects off the tightly “g formation of SBDs. Three towering columns of smoke to the south serve as a reminder of the morning's battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best peers through his binoculars. The Hiryu lies ninetee thousand feet below him, surrounded by a phalanx of battleships, cruisers and destroyers. As Best lowers his binoculars, he notices a glint of meta from an approaching aircraft. He clicks his intercom.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Get ready, Murray. We're not sneaking up on them this time. Best glances down at the Hiryu again, noting from the wak that she's turning to starboard, and then makes a hand si out the window at his wingman.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Here they come! Tracers streak the air as a dozen Zeroes slam into the formation. A SBD directly ahead of us explodes -- the percussion shaking our plane -- and Best pulls up to avoi the fiery wreckage. AS we emerge on the other side of the smoke, Best realize that his wingmen have fallen behind.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: (into radio) Stay on me, dammit! And with those final words Best hits his flaps. Meanwhile Murray sees a pair of Zeroes locking onto their tail. We expect him to flinch as usual, but this time he swings th .30 cals into position and unleashes a barrage... ...just as Best pushes the plane over into a steep dive. Murray flies out of his seat, weightless, and desperately grabs the barrel of the guns for support. His skin hisses e touches the red-hot metal and Murray yelps in pain -- -- but then he notices that the Zeroes are still on their tail. Murray grits his teeth, wedges himself into the coc and grabs the guns with his burned hands. There's no fear his eyes; only determination. The .30 cals chatter back into action, driving back the swarming Zeroes. Best's voice rings through the intercom.  113.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Murray! Altitude!

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: We've got Zeroes on our tail. Best grunts to himself and then glances back and forth be the bombsight and the rapidly-approaching carrier. Feroci flak is bursting on either side of the plane, and the air shakes as fragments piece the wings. But Best just keeps his eyes locked on his target. Bombs splash in the water off her starboard side as the elusive Hiryu tightens her turn to avoid her attackers. Best touches his flaps, flying by instinct. The sound gro muffled as he locks on the rising sun painted on the cent of the carrier's deck. We're watching a man utterly in hi element; this is what he was born to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon stares up at the dive bombers as they fall from the sky. He focuses on the plane streaking straight for the c of his deck. The pilot is silhouetted by the setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best stares through his windscreen at the bridge. He's ba twelve hundred feet above the carrier.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can't shake these damn Zeroes! Best ignores him and yanks the bomb release lever -- -- just as another burst of flak explodes practically on their wing. Best slams into the edge of the cockpit as th plane violently lurches sideways -- -- but we FALL with the bomb as it makes a beeline direct for the center of Hiryu's deck. It strikes the painted in of the red rising sun and pierces the wood like a bullet. For an instant we get a glimpse of the hangar deck as the bomb penetrates the ship. And then... BOOM! The sound is deafening in the enclosed space as pla and men are hurled away from the cataclysmic explosion. Dick Best has just become the first (and only) aviator in history to hit two enemy Carriers in one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship lurches as the explosion rips at her heart. But guns keep firing at the attacking SBDs. One of the planes never pulls out of its dive and SLAMS i the ocean at terminal velocity.  114. At that speed the water is like cement, and the plane is practically vaporized. Was it Best?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamon stand rooted in place, staring in shock at the burn hole in the center of his flight deck. He glances up just as the next squadron of SBDs begins th runs and watches, eerily detached, as one bomb heads stra for the central elevator. But an instant before it detona Kaku grabs him and pulls him back inside the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: KAKU
dialogues.text: Admiral, you must -- KA-BOOM! The thousand-pound bomb explodes on the edge of elevator. The force of the blast hurls a massive portion the lift toward the island -- -- and it slams into the front of the bridge. The impact shatters the windows and throws the officers to the floor One unfortunate crewmember is ejected out the back balcon and falls screaming to the ocean below. The men slowly push themselves to their feet, stunned to alive. A firm voice carries through the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Every man on damage control. We must save this ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is low on the horizon. The destroyer Phelps bobs few hundred feet from the Enterprise as a launch speeds t the carrier. In the bow of the launch sits... ...Dickinson. He has a black eye and a bandage on his che but he’s otherwise unharmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickinson scrambles up a ladder and emerges onto the deck Mechanics are swarming over the fifteen planes that retur from the mission, but flight operations have ceased. McClusky approaches Dickinson, one arm in a sling. He hol out his other hand. As they shake --

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: You're a sight for sore eyes. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Ran out of fuel twenty miles out. Ditched next to the Phelps.  115.

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: Didn't you serve on the Phelps?

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: First two_ years out of the academy. Funny world... Dickinson shakes his head, momentarily overwhelmed. It's been a hell of day. Then -- h \ DICKINSON (CONT'D) Where's Best?

dialogues.speaker: MCCLUSKY
dialogues.text: He went back out to hit the last Jap carrier. Hasn't come home yet. The news takes the breath out of Dickinson. He turns towa the low sun and scans the sky for any sign of a plane. But there's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann hurries up the path to a clapboard cottage and knocks the door. A moment later LAURA MCCLUSKY, 29, answers.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: You have news? Laura nods and then ushers Ann into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-dozen nervous Navy wives are gathered in the livin room. Laura gestures at a woman holding a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Cindy heard a rumor from the base. There's a big battle. One of our carriers is sinking. Ann's heart catches in her throat.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: And the pilots?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It sounds like we lost a lot of them. These women have been conditioned for tough times -- stif upper lip is their motto -- so Ann forces herself to just nod. But Laura reads her expression.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drink?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Please. I just need to use the bathroom first.  116. Ann gives the other wives a tight smile and then walks do the hall and slips into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann closes the door, her hand shaking slightly, and then stares into the mirror through hollow eyes. She has a premonition that everything is not going to be okay. And she's very scared and very alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spruance peers down at the map, arms crossed. He finally turns to Browning.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: The Japanese might charge with their battleships. So we will withdraw for the night.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BROWNING
dialogues.text: But their fleet might be out of range in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL SPRUANCE
dialogues.text: Nimitz ordered us to be judicious. We won a great victory today. Let's not blow it. The radar officer abruptly spins in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: RADAR OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sir! We got something inbound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatch's wary eyes continually scan the sky, exhaustion e on his face. His radio crackles:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Bogies twenty degrees southwest of your position. Prepare to intercept.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Copy, Enterprise. Thatch shoves the throttle forward and banks the Wildcat a steep turn. He locks on a distant speck in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've got visual. The engine growls as Thatch closes the gap. The speck tur into a plane, but as his fingers tighten on the trigger another voice echoes through his radio.

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Wildcat. You fire at me, and I'll kick your ass up and down the big E's deck when we land.  117. Thatch's face splits in a huge grin.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Roger that. Thatch whips the Wildcat around to fly in formation off t SBD's wing. He can see Best in his cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you take the scenic route home?

dialogues.speaker: BEST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Wanted to see our morning's work.

dialogues.speaker: THATCH
dialogues.text: Well, don't blow your landing. Everyone's going to be watching. Best smiles and then gives him a mock salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The western sky is ablaze with a fiery sunset, perhaps in honor of the remarkable day. Best's SBD hits the deck and grabs the first arresting wire, as always. When the propeller slows to a halt, a crowd of men rush t the plane. Dickinson is the first to reach it, and he pul himself up to the cockpit. He and Best stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Thought you were dead.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: They said the same thing about you.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Glad they were wrong. The men share a look -- so much unsaid -- and then Dickin hands him a flask of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Medicinal. Admiral's orders. Best jerks his finger at the back seat, where a drained M is unstrapping himself.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Give it to Murray. He earned it. Best swings himself out of the cockpit, but as he hits th deck his knees buckle and he launches into a violent coug fit. Dickinson watches with concern.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Are you okay?  118. Best stays bent over, body wracked by spasms. When it fin subsides, he spits blood onto the wood planking. Dickinson's worry immediately graduates into full-blown p He throws his arm around his friend.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to the sick bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A desperate group of men wearing gas masks work in thick smoke, lit by red emergency lights. The paint on the ceil is blackening from the heat of the fire above and burning flecks occasionally fall like apocalyptic snow. A gauge on the main turbine sinks toward zero, and one of the men frantically shouts at the others. They rush to tw a valve, but the gauge continues to sink until -- -- the noise from the engines abruptly stops. An instant later the room falls into total darkness. The ceiling, however, still glows a faint red from the infernal heat a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cruiser and two destroyers circle the listing carrier, spraying water onto the fires that have breached her deck Tamon stands near the rear elevator. He stares down into darkness of the hangar, head shaking.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Without power we can't stop the fires.

dialogues.speaker: KAKU
dialogues.text: Our men will fight to the death.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Of course. But I won't sacrifice them if the battle is already lost. The signal officer runs up to them and salutes Tamon.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sir! A message from Admiral Yamamoto. The main body is continuing forward for a night action. He orders us to scuttle the carrier immediately so that it doesn't fall into enemy hands. Tamon thinks for a long moment, turning the words over in his head. He finally glances at Kaku.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Gather the men.  119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remaining crew members stand at attention on the aft the flight deck, lit by the eerie light from the fires. T is perched on a box at the front of the group. His voice carries clearly to his men.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: You have all fought valiantly. The loss of this battle falls on the heads of your commanders, not you. For that reason I have decided to go down with the ship. There's a gasp from the group, followed by various cries protest. Tamon raises his hands for silence.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You will avenge this defeat and become the core of an even more powerful Japanese Navy. My final order is that you carry on your loyal service to the Emperor. Tamon snaps his heels together and then turns to face wes

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Banzai! The men shout three banzais in response, the words ringin around the deck of the doomed carrier. When the echo fade bugles PLAY the Japanese national anthem as the giant bat flags are lowered from the mast. Tamon turns to Kaku, who stands in the front row.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Abandon ship. Kaku snaps at a lieutenant, who blows a whistle. The men form orderly lines at the stern and begin to lower themse on ropes to the waiting lifeboats. Meanwhile, a small cluster of officers gather around Tamo They stand in awkward silence, nobody sure what to say, u the QUARTERMASTER clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERMASTER
dialogues.text: There's still money in the ship's safe.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: Leave it. I'll need it for a square meal in hell. Tamon smiles slightly at his own joke, but the other offi are hollow-eyed. Kaku finally speaks.

dialogues.speaker: KAKU
dialogues.text: I want to stay with you.  120. Tamon's expression turns serious. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TAMON
dialogues.text: I'm touched by your offer, but you young men must leave the ship. That's my final order. Kaku struggles to keep from bursting into tears and then draws himself up in a salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of survivors from Hiryu cling to every available spot, eyes locked on their ship. The loudspeakers blare:

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Battle station torpedo port side. Target Hiryu bearing ninety degrees. The torpedo drops into the water with a hiss. Men are ope weeping, clutching the railings for support. Kaku stands at the fantail, tears running down his cheeks His eyes are locked on a lonely figure standing at attent next to the Hiryu's island. It's Tamon. Holding a silent vigil. THUD! The torpedo detonates near the carrier's starboard bow, nearly driving the ship's prow out of the water. Kaku looks back at the island, but Tamon is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yamamoto sits ramrod straight in a chair, the deep bags u his eyes the only sign of his exhaustion. Three of his officers warily approach.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Our scouts found nothing . The American carriers must have withdrawn overnight. An emotional young flag officer can't contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: FLAG OFFICER
dialogues.text: We should push forward and bombard Midway with our guns. The Americans have no battleships. We can still win this battle. Yamamoto has been stone-faced throughout the exchange, bu he shakes his head at the final comment.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: We have no air cover. And we all learned about the weaknesses of battleships at Pearl Harbor.  121. Yamamoto turns to the young flag officer, who shrinks und his baleful stare.

dialogues.speaker: YAMAMOTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've been playing too much shogi. We cannot gamble the rest of the fleet to save our pride.

dialogues.speaker: FLAG OFFICER
dialogues.text: Then what are your orders, sir? Yamamoto weighs the impossible question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual bustle of the room has been replaced by silence Rochefort stares down at an intercepted message. Everyone watches him, waiting for his reaction. And then a slow smile spreads across Rochefort's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz maintains his weary vigil at the front of the room Layton and the exhausted staff officers update the map. Rochefort bursts into the room, waving the message over h head like a trophy.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHEFORT
dialogues.text: The Japanese are retreating. Everyone stares him. The news takes a moment to process.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: We won. Rochefort nods. And then the room erupts in a wild celebration. Rochefort and Layton hug as staff officers p each other on the back. Nimitz watches his men, briefly letting himself enjoy the moment, and then walks into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nimitz closes the door behind him and takes a deep breath And then he calls to his sleepy secretary.

dialogues.speaker: NIMITZ
dialogues.text: Get me Halsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halsey stands in his hospital gown with the phone pressed against his ear, staring out the window at Pearl Harbor. His eyes are once again wet, but this time his expression somewhere between satisfaction and relief.  122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam is reading on the couch. The front door opens and Layton enters, carrying a brown paper bag. Miriam gives h a confused look.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing home?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: I thought we might have lunch. Layton opens the bag and pulls out a bottle of wine and a loaf of bread. Miriam's brow furrows.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Did something happen? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Actually, it's a good day. And I want to celebrate with my wife. Miriam reads Layton's expression and sees an unaccustomed sparkle in his eyes. She stands and kisses him on the che

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I'll get something on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door creaks open and Best enters. We've always seen t room filled with life, but now it's empty except for aban playing cards and magazines and... ...Dickinson. He's leaning against the desk, staring at t ready board. Best follows his gaze and sees the grim real over half of their friends are dead or missing. After a long moment --

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: What happened to that whiskey? Dickinson turns his head at the familiar voice and then s a flask out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: I saved it just in case you snuck out of the infirmary. Dickinson hands him the flask, and Best grabs a pair of c mugs and pours two shots. He raises his mug in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: To Cliff Janz and the rest of the men on Arizona. To the good men we lost today and the good men we'll lose tomorrow. To the...  123. The words trail off as Best is caught up in emotion. Dick is briefly paralyzed -- he's never seen his friend this r and vulnerable -- but then he raises his own mug.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: To those in peril on the sea. Best nods; the old toast is perfect for this moment. The shoot the whiskey, and then Dickinson stands and walks ov to the door. But he pauses before exiting.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Best turns his head to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We did it. Best and Dickinson trade a long look. And then Dickinson disappears down the hallway, peaving Best alone to contem the list of the missing and the dead. AS we go CLOSE on Best's face, we see his pain -- both physical and emotional. Yet beneath the pain is something else: exhilaration. Dickinson is right. Yes, much hard fighting remains, but the darkest of hours the courage of this small fraternity men has turned the tide of war in the Pacific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Enterprise sails down the channel, her battle flags proudly flying from the mast and the crew standing at attention on the deck. Dozens of planes pass overhead in formation as her air group buzzes the harbor. The shores are lined with cheering men and women -- soldi from Fort Kamehameha and Hickam, and patients and doctors from Hospital Point. The crew of the other warships in th harbor line their own decks, sirens and whistles sounding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a joyous scene as men pour off the Enterprise to rendezvous with their friends and families. Layton stands away from the commotion and watches the men disembark, an expression of quiet satisfaction on his fac He's content to enjoy this moment from the shadows until -- Best rolls up to him in a wheelchair. He's pale and ha lost at least ten pounds. He stares up at Layton.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Hey, remember me? We met once in the bar at the Pink Palace.  124.

dialogues.speaker: LAYTON
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember. Layton's tone is wary; he doesn't want to get burned agai But Best sticks out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Hell of a job. You intelligence guys really came through for us. Layton takes Best's hand and shakes, fighting to keep his emotions in check. He never expected this kind of validat certainly not from a flyboy. But Nimitz was right; even t he isn't on the front lines in a destroyer or dive bomber he has nevertheless done something truly meaningful. Best, meanwhile, turns away and continues to wheel himsel down the wharf. His eyes desperately search the scene unt he finally sees... ...Ann and Barbera. They're wearing matching Sunday dress When Barbera notices her father, she dashes through the c and hurls herself onto his lap.

dialogues.speaker: BARBERA
dialogues.text: Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: Easy, sweetie. Best hugs his daughter and then gingerly stands to greet Ann. Her relief emerges in a breathtaking smile. But it f into concern as she gets a closer look at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I inhaled caustic soda. Apparently it activated my latent tuberculosis.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: My lungs are shot. The Navy's never going to let me fly again. The words involuntarily burst out of Ann's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: BEST
dialogues.text: I'm a pilot, Ann. This is the one thing I'm good at.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Well, get good at something else. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've got the rest of your life to figure it out. Best hears the wisdom in those words, and he pulls his wi into an embrace. They hold each other tightly, tears in t eyes -- overwhelmingly grateful for the miracle that has brought them back together. We leave them in this most intimate of moments and_ CRANE UPWARDS, revealing the remarkable panorama of Pearl Harbo Enterprise is berthed just hundreds of yards from the wre of the Arizona, the ship that she avenged. As we PULL BACK further, we see the new ships and new construction projects around the harbor: the beginnings o what will soon become the world's mightiest war machine. But we keep RISING and PULLING BACK until we're finally focused on just the vast, endless ocean -- an ocean that tried and tested the will of everyone in our story: Japan and American alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waves lap over the camera lens, a scrap of wreckage bobbi in the foreground. A yellow life raft heaves into the fra Gay lies in the bottom, badly sunburned. He stares up at clouds with a vacant look in his eye. SUPER: "Ensign Gay, the lone survivor of his squadron, sp several days adrift in the Pacific before being rescued."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of Japanese soldiers walk single-file through the thick jungle. One of them points silently at the trees ab them, which have been cropped as if by a mysterious force SUPER: "A year after Midway, American codebreakers -- led Edwin Layton -- intercepted Yamamoto's travel itinerary." The men continue into a clearing, where they discover a crashed Mitsubishi G4M bomber. The wings are sheared off the cabin is split open by the force of the wreck. SUPER: "Admiral Nimitz personally ordered a squadron of fighters to shoot down Yamamoto's transport plane." One of the soldiers points at a tree on the far side of t clearing where... ...Yamamoto is propped upright, dead. Dried blood from a head wound covers his formal uniform and one white-gloved hand still grips his katana sword. SUPER: "Yamamoto was buried with full honors."  126.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of carriers and battleships from the mighty Americ fleet fill the anchorage, guns trained on the city. Count fighters and bombers pass overhead in a thunderous format SUPER: "On September 2, 1945 the US Pacific Fleet sailed into Tokyo Bay."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of khaki-clad soldiers and sailors stand at atte as a small delegation of Japanese officials make their wa toward a wood table. SUPER: "Admiral Nimitz was chosen to sign the official surrender documents on behalf of the United States." As Nimitz raises his pen, we notice Layton standing under one of the giant sixteen-inch gun turrets. SUPER: "In recognition of his contributions to the war ef Nimitz invited Layton to attend as his personal guest." Further down the deck stand three familiar officers ina tight group, bright smiles on their faces. SUPER: "Dickinson, Thatch and McClusky survived the war. three men eventually became admirals in the US Navy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn leaves swirl on the main quad. A crowd has gathere on the lawn between the beautiful chapel and the imposing facade of Bancroft Hall. SUPER: "Dick Best spent three years after Midway in a Nav Hospital and never flew again. He eventually became direc of security for the Rand Corporation." As we draw closer to the crowd, we find hundreds of Midsh and civilians sitting in neat rows of chairs. They're fac a brand-new stone monument honoring the Battle of Midway.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: REAR ADMIRAL SAMUEL LOCKLEAR, 42, speaks from the podium next to a row of dignitaries.

dialogues.speaker: READ ADMIRAL LOCKLEAR
dialogues.text: In the memorable words of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, 'There is a mysterious cycle in human events. To some generations, much is given. Of other generations, much is expected. Locklear turns to look at a figure standing off-camera.  127.

dialogues.speaker: READ ADMIRAL LOCKLEAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Today, as we dedicate this monument to the memory of the brave men who fought for liberty, we are honored to have one of the last surviving Midway pilots with us. Lieutenant Commander Richard Halsey Best. As the crowd rises to applaud, we focus on a camera whirr near the back of the group. We PUSH into the viewfinder u a VHS image fills our screen... ...and suddenly we are watching footage of the real DICK BEST, age 86, speaking at the ceremony. He stands proudly his dinner dress uniform, his back ramrod straight, the l survivor of his squadron.

dialogues.speaker: DICK BEST
dialogues.text: I guess it's my job to speak for the guys who can't be here. We lost a lot of good men that day, and a lot more since. But I'm glad to know that we're remembered. (beat ) People often ask me about Midway. How I could fly against those odds, knowing that I probably wasn't going to come back. Best stares out at this new generation of Naval officers, determined to pass along the one lesson he truly learned.

dialogues.speaker: DICK BEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Those men were my brothers. I would have flown with them straight into Hell. We take one final look at this remarkable man, the faint growl of a distant engine in our ear, and then...

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: SUPER: "Dick Best died in Santa Monica, California at the age of 91. He is buried alongside many of his friends and fellow pilots at Arlington National Cemetery."
